questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Six friends - P, Q, R, S, T, and U are sitting around a circular table facing the center. Each one of them is wearing a different colored shirt: Red, Green, Blue, Yellow, White, and Black. The following conditions are given: 1) P sits second to the right of Q. 2) R is not an immediate neighbor of Q. 3) The one in Red is opposite the one in White. 4) S is sitting next to the one in Yellow and the one in Black. 5) T sits to the immediate left of the one in Blue. Who is sitting opposite the one in Green?
questions.explanation: Based on the conditions: P sits second to the right of Q, which helps place P and Q relative to each other. Since R is not an immediate neighbor of Q, and S is next to Yellow and Black, we can deduce their positions. Since T is to the immediate left of Blue, we can arrange the remaining friends and colors accordingly. S, who wears the Red shirt, ends up sitting opposite the one in Green.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Seven friends - A, B, C, D, E, F, and G are sitting around a circular table. Some are facing the center while others are facing outside. The following information is known: 1) A is third to the right of C, who is facing the center. 2) B sits second to the left of A. 3) E, who is facing outside, is an immediate neighbor of both F and G. 4) D is third to the right of G, who faces the center. 5) F faces the center. Who is facing outside?
questions.explanation: With C and F facing the center, and A positioned relative to C, B must be placed accordingly. Since E is facing outside, immediate neighbors must be identified, taking into account G’s position (facing the center), and D’s position in relation to G. Thus, B and E are facing outside.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Eight people - H, I, J, K, L, M, N, and O are seated around a circular table. Some of them face the center, while others face outside. 1) L is to the immediate right of K, who is third to the right of J. 2) H is facing the center and is second to the left of M. 3) N is third to the right of M, who faces outside. 4) I is not an immediate neighbor of J. 5) Both the immediate neighbors of H are facing outside. 6) O is facing the center. Who sits directly opposite H?
questions.explanation: Positioning H based on M's position, facing outside, helps place immediate neighbors. O faces the center, and with H facing the center, and both neighbors of H facing outside, O’s position is opposite to H.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Nine people - P, Q, R, S, T, U, V, W, and X are sitting around a circular table facing either the center or outside. The conditions are: 1) P sits third to the left of Q, who faces the center. 2) R is not an immediate neighbor of Q. 3) Only two people sit between R and S. 4) V, who is facing outside, is an immediate neighbor of both T and W. 5) U sits second to the right of R. 6) X is not an immediate neighbor of Q. 7) The immediate neighbors of U face the center. Who sits second to the left of W?
questions.explanation: Placing Q with P according to the conditions, and then determining the placement of R and S, helps fix U’s position, while confirming neighbors’ directions. Establishing V’s outside-facing, adjacent positions (T and W) allows confirmation of neighbors’ (U) directions facing the center, solidifying X’s relative position second left of W.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Ten colleagues - A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I, and J are sitting around a circular table. Some are facing the center, others are facing outside. The following is known: 1) B sits third to the right of E, who faces the center. 2) G is not an immediate neighbor of E. 3) Both the immediate neighbors of B face outside. 4) I sits third to the left of G, who faces the center. 5) C is an immediate neighbor of both A and D. 6) H is second to the right of C. 7) The immediate neighbors of A face the center. 8) F is not an immediate neighbor of D. Who sits opposite G?
questions.explanation: Start with placing E facing center with B's placement. G's position allows I's placement. B’s immediate neighbors face outside, aiding placement of other members, aligning A’s neighbors facing center. Confirm C between A and D, enables H and others’ positioning, pinpointing J directly opposite G.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Six friends - P, Q, R, S, T, and U are sitting around a circular table facing the center. Who is sitting to the immediate right of R?

Conditions:
1. P sits second to the right of Q.
2. R is sitting to the immediate left of U.
3. S sits third to the left of T.
4. U is not an immediate neighbor of T.
questions.explanation: Start by placing Q, who is seated. P is second to the right of Q. R is immediately left of U, so place R and U together. Since U cannot be next to T, consider the placement that satisfies all conditions. The final arrangement is Q - P - S - T - U - R. Thus, Q is to the immediate right of R.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Eight people - A, B, C, D, E, F, G, and H are sitting around a circular table. Some are facing the center while others are facing outside. Who is directly opposite to F?

Conditions:
1. A sits second to the left of B, who faces the center.
2. D is an immediate neighbor of A and sits third to the right of F.
3. C sits second to the right of H, who is not an immediate neighbor of D.
4. E sits opposite to G.
5. Both immediate neighbors of G face outside.
questions.explanation: Place B and determine A's position since B faces the center. Position D and F according to their relationship. Using the conditions that G's neighbors face outside and E sits opposite G, we adjust the positions. The final arrangement shows D sits opposite to F.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Seven people - L, M, N, O, P, Q, and R are sitting around a circular table. Who is sitting to the immediate left of P?

Conditions:
1. L sits second to the right of N.
2. M is an immediate neighbor of L.
3. O sits third to the left of Q.
4. R is not an immediate neighbor of Q.
5. P sits directly opposite to N.
questions.explanation: Place N and then L according to the conditions. Since M is an immediate neighbor of L, we place M. With O positioned relative to Q and R not near Q, the placement of P opposite N results in M sitting to the immediate left of P.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Nine people - A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, and I are sitting around a circular table, with some facing the center and others facing outside. Who is to the immediate right of G?

Conditions:
1. A, facing outside, sits third to the left of I.
2. B sits second to the right of H, who faces the center.
3. F is not an immediate neighbor of A.
4. C sits opposite to E, who faces the center.
5. D sits third to the right of G, who faces outside.
6. Immediate neighbors of C face the center.
questions.explanation: Start by placing I and then A (facing outside) in relative position. B's placement is adjusted to fit next to H, as B is second right of H. With F not next to A, adjust positions of F and others. D's position helps place G (facing outside), and thus B sits to the immediate right of G.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Ten friends - J, K, L, M, N, O, P, Q, R, and S are sitting around a circular table. Who is sitting directly opposite J?

Conditions:
1. M sits second to the right of K.
2. L sits third to the left of O, who is facing outside.
3. N sits to the immediate right of P.
4. S is not an immediate neighbor of Q.
5. R sits opposite to P, who faces the center.
6. Immediate neighbors of J face the same direction as J.
7. Q sits second to the right of S.
8. K and J face opposite directions.
questions.explanation: First, place K and M, which allows the placement of P opposite R, with P facing the center. Place O facing outside, then L. J's placement depends on neighbors facing the same direction. Q's position is defined by S. Through process of elimination, M is found to be directly opposite J.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Six friends A, B, C, D, E, and F are sitting around a circular table facing the center. 1) A sits second to the right of B. 2) D is not an immediate neighbor of B. 3) C sits third to the left of F. 4) E sits between D and F. Who is sitting immediately to the right of E?
questions.explanation: Place B first. A sits second to the right of B, so possible placements for A and B are verified. Next, since D is not next to B, place D accordingly. C sits third to the left of F, and E sits between D and F. This confirms E's placement and who sits next to E.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Seven colleagues P, Q, R, S, T, U, and V are seated in a circle facing the center. 1) P is second to the left of Q. 2) R is third to the right of T. 3) S is not an immediate neighbor of P. 4) V is to the immediate left of U. 5) S is between U and T. Who is exactly opposite T?
questions.explanation: Start with P and Q, placing P second to the left of Q. Then place R, who is third to the right of T. V is placed left of U, and S between U and T. This creates a unique arrangement confirming R's position opposite T.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Eight friends J, K, L, M, N, O, P, and Q are sitting around a circle, some facing the center and some facing outside. 1) J sits second to the right of K, who faces the center. 2) L sits third to the left of M. 3) N sits second to the left of L. 4) O is not an immediate neighbor of J. 5) P is third to the right of N. 6) J and L face the same direction. Who is sitting opposite O?
questions.explanation: Position K facing the center and place J accordingly. Then place L third to the left of M, and N second to the left of L. P is placed relative to N, and the direction clues help solve remaining placements. This confirms N is opposite O.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Nine friends A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, and I are sitting around a circular table. 1) C is third to the right of A. 2) B is second to the left of G, who is facing the center. 3) H is facing outside and is second to the right of B. 4) I is third to the left of D, who is facing the center. 5) A is not next to E. 6) F is fourth to the right of I, who faces the center. Who sits to the immediate left of E?
questions.explanation: Place G and B first based on their conditions. Using the directions and relative positions of H and others, build the seating arrangement. Position A, C, D, and I according to the rules, filling gaps with known placements. This confirms E's left neighbor.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Ten people P, Q, R, S, T, U, V, W, X, and Y are sitting around a circle, some facing the center and some facing outside. 1) P is third to the right of Q, who faces the center. 2) R is not adjacent to P. 3) S is fourth to the left of T, facing the center. 4) U is not an immediate neighbor of Q. 5) V sits to the immediate left of W, who faces outside. 6) X sits third to the right of Y, and both face the same direction. 7) T sits second to the left of U, facing the center. Who sits opposite S?
questions.explanation: Start with Q facing the center and place P. Ensure R is not adjacent. Position S based on T's location, ensuring correct directions. V, W, and X are placed using their relative positions and directions. Fill remaining spots while confirming everyone fits. This places P opposite S.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Six friends A, B, C, D, E, and F are sitting around a circular table facing the center. 1) A sits second to the right of B. 2) C is an immediate neighbor of B. 3) D sits third to the right of C. 4) E is not an immediate neighbor of A. Who sits immediately to the left of E?
questions.explanation: Following the conditions: A sits second to the right of B and C is a neighbor of B, we can determine that the sequence B, C, A is fixed. D sits third to the right of C, placing D directly opposite B. Since E is not a neighbor of A, the final sequence is: B, C, F, A, E, D. Thus, D sits immediately to the left of E.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Seven people P, Q, R, S, T, U, and V are sitting around a circular table, some facing the center and some facing outside. 1) P sits third to the left of Q, and Q faces the center. 2) R is not an immediate neighbor of P or Q. 3) U sits second to the right of S, who faces the center. 4) V sits third to the left of T, both facing the same direction. 5) U faces outside. Who sits opposite to S?
questions.explanation: Q faces the center with P third to the left, meaning P faces outside. U is second right of S, placing U opposite to S and facing outside. V and T face the same direction, and V is third to the left of T. The complete sequence adhering to all conditions results in V sitting opposite to S.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Eight friends L, M, N, O, P, Q, R, and S are sitting in a circle, some facing the center and some facing outside. 1) L sits second to the right of N, who faces the center. 2) P is not a neighbor of L or N. 3) M sits third to the left of R, and both M and R face the same direction. 4) Q sits second to the right of P. 5) S sits third to the right of O, who faces outside. Who sits to the immediate right of Q?
questions.explanation: Following the conditions: N faces the center, L is second to the right of N. M and R face the same direction, positioning M opposite P. Q is second to the right of P, placing S as immediate right to Q following all conditions and deductions.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Nine people A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, and I are sitting in a circle, facing either center or outside. 1) B sits second to the left of C, who faces the center. 2) E is an immediate neighbor of both B and D. 3) G sits third to the left of E, facing the same direction as E. 4) H is not an immediate neighbor of G or C. 5) A sits third to the right of I, who faces the center. 6) F is second to the left of H. Who sits to the immediate right of A?
questions.explanation: B is placed second left of C. G and E face the same way. A is third to the right of I, both facing inward. Given F's and H's constraints, E logically falls to the immediate right of A based on condition fulfillment and spatial deductions.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Ten people J, K, L, M, N, O, P, Q, R, and S are sitting in a circle, facing either center or outside. 1) J sits second to the right of K, who faces outside. 2) L sits third to the left of N, and they face opposite directions. 3) P is not an immediate neighbor of J or K. 4) Q is fourth to the right of M, who faces the center. 5) R sits second to the left of O, who faces the same direction as Q. 6) S is an immediate neighbor of both J and N. 7) M is not next to R. Who sits opposite L?
questions.explanation: Following the directions, K and J are placed with J second right of K. L and N oppose each other. The positioning of R and O plus other constraints places Q opposite L through logical deductions fulfilling all conditions.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a certain code language, 'DOG' is written as 'EHF'. How is 'CAT' written in that code?
questions.explanation: The coding rule involves shifting each letter one position forward in the alphabet. D becomes E, O becomes H, and G becomes F. Applying the same rule to 'CAT': C becomes D, A becomes B, and T becomes U. Hence, 'CAT' is written as 'DBU'.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a code language, 'BIRD' is written as 'CJTF', and 'FISH' is written as 'GJTI'. How is 'DUCK' coded?
questions.explanation: The pattern involves shifting each vowel in the word by +1 and each consonant by +2. 'BIRD': B (2+2=4=D), I (9+1=10=J), R (18+2=20=T), D (4+2=6=F). Apply the same rule to 'DUCK': D (4+2=6=E), U (21+1=22=V), C (3+2=5=F), K (11+2=13=L). Thus, 'DUCK' is coded as 'EVFL'.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: If 'GARDEN' is coded as 'IBSEQO' and 'FLOWER' is coded as 'HNUYGT', how will 'PLANTS' be coded?
questions.explanation: The pattern involves shifting the odd-positioned letters by +2 and even-positioned letters by +4. 'GARDEN': G(+2)=I, A(+4)=E, R(+2)=T, D(+4)=H, E(+2)=G, N(+4)=R. Applying the pattern to 'PLANTS': P(+2)=R, L(+4)=N, A(+2)=C, N(+4)=Q, T(+2)=V, S(+4)=U, resulting in 'RNCPVU'.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a code language, 'TIGER' is encoded as 'VGJKT' and 'LION' is encoded as 'NJMR'. How would you encode 'BEAR'?
questions.explanation: The pattern involves shifting the first letter by +2, the second by +1, the third by +3, the fourth by -1, and the fifth by +1. 'TIGER': T(+2)=V, I(+1)=J, G(+3)=J, E(-1)=D, R(+1)=S. 'BEAR': B(+2)=D, E(+1)=F, A(+3)=D, R(-1)=Q. Therefore, 'BEAR' is coded as 'DFCT'.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: If 'COMPUTER' is coded as 'DNQVRVGT', and 'PRINTER' is coded as 'QSJOUFS', then what does 'KEYBOARD' become?
questions.explanation: The coding pattern involves shifting each letter forward by one in the alphabet. 'COMPUTER': C(+1)=D, O(+1)=P, M(+1)=N, etc. 'PRINTER': P(+1)=Q, R(+1)=S, etc. Applying this pattern to 'KEYBOARD': K(+1)=L, E(+1)=F, Y(+1)=Z, B(+1)=C, O(+1)=P, A(+1)=B, R(+1)=S, D(+1)=E. Therefore, 'KEYBOARD' is coded as 'LFZCSDRE'.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a certain code, 'CAT' is written as 'DBU'. How is 'DOG' written in that code?
questions.explanation: The pattern is to replace each letter with the next letter in the alphabet. C becomes D, A becomes B, and T becomes U. Hence, for DOG: D -> E, O -> P, G -> H. Therefore, DOG becomes EPH.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a certain code, 'HELLO' is coded as 'JGNNQ' and 'WORLD' is coded as 'YQTNF'. How is 'LOGIC' coded in that code?
questions.explanation: The pattern involves shifting each letter by +2 in the alphabet. H -> J, E -> G, L -> N, etc. Applying the same logic to LOGIC: L -> N, O -> Q, G -> I, I -> K, C -> E. Thus, LOGIC becomes NRJKE.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: If 'SKILL' is coded as 'TMJMN' and 'LOGIC' is coded as 'MPHJG', how is 'RULE' coded in that language?
questions.explanation: The pattern involves shifting consonants by +1 and vowels by -1. For SKILL: S(+1)=T, K(+1)=L, I(-1)=H, L(+1)=M. Similarly, for RULE: R(+1)=S, U(-1)=T, L(+1)=M, E(-1)=D. Thus, RULE becomes SVNF.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a certain code, 'MARKET' is written as 'NZXLZG' and 'GOOGLE' is written as 'HPHPMG'. How is 'INDIGO' coded in that code?
questions.explanation: The pattern involves alternating +1 and -1 shifts: M+1=N, A-1=Z, R+1=S, K-1=J, E+1=F, T-1=S for MARKET. Applying the same to INDIGO: I+1=J, N-1=M, D+1=E, I-1=H, G+1=H, O-1=N. Thus, INDIGO becomes JOEJHP.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a certain code, 'PROGRAMMING' is written as 'SQSHQAVODNR' and 'SOFTWARE' is written as 'TQFUXFSD'. How is 'DEVELOPER' coded in that language?
questions.explanation: The pattern is to shift odd-positioned letters by +1 and even-positioned letters by -1. For 'PROGRAMMING': P(+1)=Q, R(-1)=Q, O(+1)=P, G(-1)=F, etc. For 'DEVELOPER': D(+1)=E, E(-1)=D, V(+1)=W, E(-1)=D, L(+1)=M, O(-1)=N, P(+1)=Q, E(-1)=D, R(+1)=S. Thus, DEVELOPER becomes EFAWKPFSF.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a certain code language, 'CAT' is written as 'DBU', and 'DOG' is written as 'EPH'. How is 'FOX' written in that code?
questions.explanation: The pattern involves shifting each letter in the word forward by 1 position in the alphabet. For 'CAT' to 'DBU': C+1=D, A+1=B, T+1=U. Similarly, for 'DOG' to 'EPH': D+1=E, O+1=P, G+1=H. Thus, 'FOX' will be: F+1=G, O+1=P, X+1=Y, resulting in 'GPY'.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a certain code, 'BRIGHT' is written as 'CSJHIU' and 'CLEVER' is written as 'DMFWFS'. How will 'SMART' be written in that code?
questions.explanation: The pattern involves shifting each letter forward by 1 in the alphabet. For 'BRIGHT' to 'CSJHIU': B+1=C, R+1=S, I+1=J, G+1=H, H+1=I, T+1=U. For 'CLEVER' to 'DMFWFS': C+1=D, L+1=M, E+1=F, V+1=W, E+1=F, R+1=S. Therefore, 'SMART' becomes S+1=T, M+1=N, A+1=B, R+1=S, T+1=U resulting in 'TNBVS'.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a code language, 'BLANKET' is coded as 'CMBOUFS', and 'PILLOW' is coded as 'QJMMOX'. How will 'QUILTS' be coded in that code?
questions.explanation: The pattern here is shifting each letter forward by 1 position: 'BLANKET' to 'CMBOUFS': B+1=C, L+1=M, A+1=B, N+1=O, K+1=U, E+1=F, T+1=S. Similarly, 'PILLOW' to 'QJMMOX': P+1=Q, I+1=J, L+1=M, L+1=M, O+1=P, W+1=X. Therefore, 'QUILTS' will be Q+1=R, U+1=V, I+1=J, L+1=M, T+1=U, S+1=T, resulting in 'RVMJUT'.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a certain code language, 'EXAMPLE' is written as 'FYBNQMF' and 'RANDOM' is written as 'SBOEPN'. How is 'PROCESS' written in that code?
questions.explanation: The pattern is shifting each letter forward by 1 position in the alphabet: 'EXAMPLE' to 'FYBNQMF': E+1=F, X+1=Y, A+1=B, M+1=N, P+1=Q, L+1=M, E+1=F. 'RANDOM' to 'SBOEPN': R+1=S, A+1=B, N+1=O, D+1=E, O+1=P, M+1=N. Thus 'PROCESS' becomes: P+1=Q, R+1=S, O+1=P, C+1=D, E+1=F, S+1=T, S+1=T, giving us 'QSPDFTT'.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a certain code language, 'BUTTERFLY' is written as 'CVUUFSFMAZ' and 'BEAUTIFUL' is written as 'CFBVUJGMVM'. How is 'GRACEFUL' written in that code?
questions.explanation: The pattern involves adding 1 to every consonant and subtracting 1 from every vowel: 'BUTTERFLY' to 'CVUUFSFMAZ': B+1=C, U-1=V, T+1=U, T+1=U, E-1=F, R+1=S, F+1=G, L+1=M, Y+1=Z. 'BEAUTIFUL' to 'CFBVUJGMVM': B+1=C, E-1=F, A-1=B, U-1=V, T+1=U, I-1=H, F+1=G, U-1=V, L+1=M. Thus, 'GRACEFUL' will be: G+1=H, R+1=S, A-1=Z, C+1=D, E-1=F, F+1=G, U-1=V, L+1=M, resulting in 'HSDDFUVM'.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a certain code language, 'CAT' is written as 'DBU', and 'DOG' is written as 'EPH'. How will 'BAT' be written in that code?
questions.explanation: The pattern involves shifting each letter in the word by +1. For 'CAT', C->D, A->B, T->U to become 'DBU'. Applying the same pattern to 'BAT', B->C, A->B, T->U, we get 'CBU'.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a coded language, 'BOOK' is represented as 'DQQM', and 'PEN' is represented as 'RGP'. How is 'NOTE' coded in that language?
questions.explanation: In the code, each letter is shifted by +2 positions forward. For 'BOOK', B->D, O->Q, O->Q, K->M, resulting in 'DQQM'. For 'NOTE', N->P, O->Q, T->U, E->F, resulting in 'PQUF'.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: If in a certain language, 'LION' is written as 'KIOM' and 'TIGER' as 'SJFDS', how will 'BEAR' be written?
questions.explanation: The pattern shifts vowels -1 and consonants +1. 'LION': L+1=K, I-1=H (but becomes I for vowel adjustment), O-1=N (but becomes O for vowel adjustment), N+1=O. 'BEAR': B+1=C, E-1=D (becomes E for vowel adjustment), A-1=Z (becomes A), R+1=S, resulting in 'ADFS'.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a code language, 'PROGRAM' is written as 'OQPFSLB' and 'ENCODE' is written as 'DMBNDC'. How is 'LANGUAGE' coded in that language?
questions.explanation: Each letter is alternately shifted: vowels -1, consonants +1. For 'PROGRAM': P+1=Q, R-1=O, O+1=P, G-1=F, R+1=S, A-1=L, M+1=N. Applying to 'LANGUAGE': L+1=M, A-1=Z, N+1=O, G-1=F, U+1=V, A-1=Z, G+1=H, E-1=D, resulting in 'KZMFZTFD'.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a code, 'ALGORITHM' is written as 'ZKNVRJSGN'. Similarly, 'DEVELOPER' is written as 'WVPFYLOVU'. How will 'DATABASE' be coded?
questions.explanation: Consonants are shifted -1, vowels +1. 'ALGORITHM': A+1=B, L-1=K, G-1=F, O+1=P, R-1=Q, I+1=J, T-1=S, H-1=G, M-1=L. For 'DATABASE': D-1=C, A+1=B, T-1=S, A+1=B, B-1=A, A+1=B, S-1=R, E+1=F, resulting in 'WZSGYVXY'.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: If 'CAT' is coded as 'DBU', 'DOG' is coded as 'EPH', then how is 'BAT' coded?
questions.explanation: Each letter in the word is shifted forward by 1 position in the alphabet. C becomes D, A becomes B, T becomes U. Thus, 'BAT' becomes 'CBU'.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: If 'HELLO' is coded as 'JGNNQ' and 'WORLD' is coded as 'YQTNF', how would 'BEACH' be coded?
questions.explanation: Each letter is shifted forward by 2 positions in the alphabet. B becomes D, E becomes G, A becomes C, C becomes E, and H becomes J. Thus, 'BEACH' is coded as 'DGCEJ'.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: If 'FLOWER' is coded as 'GMRXGT', and 'GARDEN' is coded as 'HCVFGP', how would 'BOTTLE' be coded?
questions.explanation: Each letter is increased by 1, then decreased by 1 for the alternate letters. B becomes C, O becomes P, T stays T, T stays T, L becomes M, and E becomes F. Thus, 'BOTTLE' is coded as 'CPUPMF'.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: If 'SUNLIGHT' is coded as 'RWOMFHSZ', and 'MOONLIGHT' is coded as 'LNNMFHSZ', how would 'STARDUST' be coded?
questions.explanation: Each letter is decreased by 1 if it's in the first half of the word and increased by 1 if in the second half, except the last letter which remains the same. S becomes R, T becomes S, A becomes Z, R becomes Q, D becomes C, U stays U, S becomes R, T stays T. Thus, 'STARDUST' becomes 'RTZQCUSR'.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: If 'ECONOMICS' is coded as 'FBPOPNJDR', and 'ANALYTICS' is coded as 'BMBMXUJDR', how would 'STATISTICS' be coded?
questions.explanation: Each letter is increased by 1 in the first half of the word, and decreased by 1 in the second half, the last three letters are kept as 'JDR' regardless. S becomes T, T becomes U, A becomes B, T becomes U, I stays I, S becomes T, T becomes S, I stays I, C becomes D, S becomes R. However, following the JDR rule for last three gives us 'JDR'. Hence, 'STATISTICS' becomes 'TUBUJXJDR'.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a certain code language, 'DOG' is coded as 'EHP', and 'CAT' is coded as 'DBU'. How is 'BAT' coded in that language?
questions.explanation: In the given code, each letter is shifted forward by 1 in the alphabet. Thus, DOG becomes EHP (D+1=E, O+1=H, G+1=P) and CAT becomes DBU (C+1=D, A+1=B, T+1=U). Therefore, BAT is coded as CBU (B+1=C, A+1=B, T+1=U).
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a certain code language, 'GARDEN' is coded as 'TZIWVG' and 'HOUSE' is coded as 'SLFIH'. How is 'PLANT' coded in that language?
questions.explanation: The pattern involves reversing the order of the word and then applying a positional letter shift of -1 (e.g., GARDEN → NEDRAG, then each letter shifts backwards: N-1=M, E-1=D, D-1=C, R-1=Q, A-1=Z, G-1=F becomes TZIWVG). Applying this to PLANT: TNALP reversed, then shifting each by -1 gives KOFMV.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a certain code, 'RAINBOW' is encoded as 'S5JMMBY'. If 'SUNSHINE' is encoded as 'T8VOIFMF', how is 'MOONLIGHT' encoded?
questions.explanation: The pattern involves shifting each letter forward by 1 and replacing the vowels with their position number in the word. For example, RAINBOW becomes S5JMMBY: R+1=S, A is 5th in the alphabet and a vowel so 5, I+1=J, N+1=M, B+1=C but encoded as M for consistency, O+1=P but encoded as B for consistency, W+1=X but encoded as Y for consistency. For SUNSHINE: T8VOIFMF follows similar rules. MOONLIGHT: N9PLMHSI where M+1=N, O is 9th vowel, etc.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a certain language, 'SUCCESS' is coded as 'RFBFDVT' and 'ACHIEVE' as 'ZBGHDWC'. What is the code for 'PROGRESS'?
questions.explanation: The pattern involves shifting consonants backward by 1 and vowels forward by 1. SUCCESS: S-1=R, U+1=V, C-1=B, C-1=B, E+1=F, S-1=R, S-1=T. Apply same pattern to PROGRESS: P-1=Q, R-1=Q, O+1=P, G-1=F, R-1=Q, E+1=F, S-1=R, S-1=T.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a certain code, 'DEVELOPMENT' is written as 'CZEKWOLBMFS', and 'INNOVATION' as 'HMMPYUSJPO'. How is 'TECHNOLOGY' encoded in this code?
questions.explanation: The pattern requires alternating shifts: consonants are shifted forward by 1, vowels are shifted backward by 1. For DEVELOPMENT: D-1=C, E+1=Z, V-1=E, E+1=K, L-1=K, O+1=W, P-1=O, M+1=L, E+1=B, N-1=M, T+1=S. For TECHNOLOGY: T-1=S, E+1=D, C-1=M, H-1=G, N-1=O, O+1=N, L-1=K, O+1=P, G-1=F, Y+1=Z.

questions.explanation: To find the value of x: (1) From Statement I: 3x + 5 = 20 gives x = 5, so Statement I alone is sufficient. (2) From Statement II: x - 2 = 3 gives x = 5, so Statement II alone is sufficient. Hence, each statement alone is sufficient to find the value of x.

What is the area of rectangle R?

Statement II: The perimeter of rectangle R is 36.

options.A: Statement I alone is sufficient, but Statement II alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
options.B: Statement II alone is sufficient, but Statement I alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
options.C: Both statements I and II together are sufficient to answer the question, but neither statement alone is sufficient.
options.D: Each statement alone is sufficient to answer the question.
options.E: Statements I and II together are not sufficient to answer the question, and additional information is needed.

questions.explanation: To determine the area of rectangle R: (1) Statement I gives a relation between length and width, but no specific dimensions, hence insufficient alone. (2) Statement II provides the perimeter but not enough to determine specific dimensions, hence insufficient alone. (3) Combining both: Let width be x, then length = 2x. Perimeter = 2(x + 2x) = 36 gives x = 6, length = 12. Area = length x width = 12 x 6 = 72. Both statements together are sufficient.

options.B: Statement II alone is sufficient, but Statement I alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
options.C: Both statements I and II together are sufficient to answer the question, but neither statement alone is sufficient.

3) Combining both, x is 8 since it is the only number between 5 and 10 that is both even and divisible by 4.

questions.question:
Is z an integer?

Statement I: z squared is a whole number.
Statement II: 2z is an integer.

options.A: Statement I alone is sufficient, but Statement II alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
options.B: Statement II alone is sufficient, but Statement I alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
options.C: Both statements I and II together are sufficient to answer the question, but neither statement alone is sufficient.
options.D: Each statement alone is sufficient to answer the question.

questions.explanation:
To determine if z is an integer:
1) Statement I alone: z squared being a whole number does not ensure z is an integer (e.g., z could be the square root of a non-perfect square like 2).
2) Statement II alone: if 2z is an integer, then z is half of an integer, which must be an integer itself since it must divide evenly to be a whole number.
3) Therefore, Statement II alone is sufficient.

Statement II: b > 5.

options.A: Statement I alone is sufficient, but Statement II alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
options.B: Statement II alone is sufficient, but Statement I alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
options.C: Both statements I and II together are sufficient to answer the question, but neither statement alone is sufficient.
options.D: Each statement alone is sufficient to answer the question.
options.E: Statements I and II together are not sufficient to answer the question, and additional information is needed.

questions.explanation:
To determine if a + b > 10:
1) Statement I alone shows a > 5, but without knowing b, a could be large or small, so insufficiency.
2) Statement II alone shows b > 5, but without knowing a, b could be large or small, so insufficiency.
3) Even together, if a = 6 and b = 5, then a + b = 11, but a = 6 and b = 6 means a + b = 12. Many combinations give varying results. Thus, neither statement alone nor both together ensure a unique answer.

options.B: Statement II alone is sufficient, but Statement I alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
options.C: Both statements I and II together are sufficient to answer the question, but neither statement alone is sufficient.
options.D: Each statement alone is sufficient to answer the question.
options.E: Statements I and II together are not sufficient to answer the question, and additional information is needed.

questions.explanation: To find John's current age, we need his brother's age 5 years ago and John's relationship to that age. (1) Statement I tells us that John's brother was 10 years old five years ago (since he's 15 now) and John was twice that age, making John 20 years old at that time, thus John is now 25. Statement I is sufficient. (2) Statement II only confirms the current age of John's brother as 15, which is already known. It does not provide any additional information about John's age. Hence, Statement II alone is not sufficient. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

(1) Statement I provides an equation with two variables (x and y), which is not sufficient to find a unique value of x. (2) Statement II provides another equation with both x and y, which alone is also insufficient. (3) Combining both statements, we have two equations with two variables: 3x + 2(2) = 10 and x - 2 = 2. Solving these gives a unique solution for x. Hence, both statements together are sufficient. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

(2) Statement II tells us b is positive, but gives no information about a's sign. Hence, it is also insufficient. options.D: Each statement alone is sufficient to answer the question.
options.E: Statements I and II together are not sufficient to answer the question, and additional information is needed.

questions.explanation: To find the average of x, y, and z, we need to know the sum x + y + z. (1) Statement I gives x + y = 10, but z is unknown. (2) Statement II gives y + z = 14, but x is unknown. (3) Even combining, we get two equations with three variables and cannot determine x + y + z. Hence, both statements together are insufficient.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Is the triangle ABC isosceles?

Statement I: AB = AC
Statement II: Angle B = Angle C

options.A: Statement I alone is sufficient, but Statement II alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
options.B: Statement II alone is sufficient, but Statement I alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
options.C: Both statements I and II together are sufficient to answer the question, but neither statement alone is sufficient.
options.D: Each statement alone is sufficient to answer the question.
options.E: Statements I and II together are not sufficient to answer the question, and additional information is needed.

questions.explanation: For a triangle to be isosceles, at least two sides or two angles must be equal. (1) Statement I alone, AB = AC, shows that the triangle is isosceles. (2) Statement II alone, Angle B = Angle C, also shows that the triangle is isosceles. Thus, each statement alone is sufficient.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
What is the value of y?

Statement I: y^2 - 4y = 0
Statement II: y is an integer.

options.A: Statement I alone is sufficient, but Statement II alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
options.B: Statement II alone is sufficient, but Statement I alone is not sufficient to answer the question.
options.C: Both statements I and II together are sufficient to answer the question, but neither statement alone is sufficient.
options.D: Each statement alone is sufficient to answer the question.
options.E: Statements I and II together are not sufficient to answer the question, and additional information is needed.

questions.explanation: To determine the value of y: (1) From Statement I, y^2 - 4y = 0 gives us y(y - 4) = 0, so y = 0 or y = 4, which are possible integer solutions. (2) Statement II merely states that y is an integer, which does not help in selecting between the possibilities without further data. Thus, Statement I alone is sufficient.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A person walks 10 meters North, then turns right and walks 10 meters, then turns right again and walks 10 meters. Which direction is the person facing now?
questions.explanation: Initially facing North, after walking 10m North, turning right (facing East), walking 10m, turning right again (facing South), walking 10m means they are now facing West.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A person starts at a point, walks 20 meters East, turns left and walks 30 meters, turns right and walks 40 meters, turns right again and walks 30 meters. What is the shortest distance back to the starting point?
questions.explanation: After all movements, the person is 20 meters East and 30 meters South of the starting point. Using the Pythagorean theorem: distance = √(20² + 30²) = √1300 = approximately 36.05 meters.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A person walks 50 meters North, turns 45° clockwise and walks 50√2 meters, then turns 135° counterclockwise and walks 50 meters. How far are they from the starting point?
questions.explanation: The first movement places them 50m North. The second movement (45° clockwise, 50√2) lands them at the same North coordinate (50m), while being 50m East. The last movement (135° counterclockwise) returns them to the original North-South axis, now 50m East. Thus, they are 100m from the start.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A person walks 30 meters East, then turns left and walks 20 meters. They turn left again and walk 30 meters. Finally, they turn right and walk 40 meters. In which direction are they from the starting point?
questions.explanation: The person ends up 20 meters South of the starting point after the sequence of movements. Facing East, turning left goes North, another left goes West, and right turns South for the final leg, placing them directly South.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A person travels 60 meters North, then 45 meters Northeast, and finally 75 meters Southeast. Determine their final displacement from the starting point.
questions.explanation: North = 60m N, then 45m at 45° adds approximately 31.82m N and 31.82m E. The 75m SE subtracts 53.03m N and adds 53.03m E. Final coordinates: 38.79m E, 38.79m N. Displacement = √(38.79² + 38.79²) = approximately 54.88m ≈ 90m considering options.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: John walks 10 meters North, then 5 meters East. What is the final direction of John from the starting point?
questions.explanation: From the starting point, John moves 10 meters North and then 5 meters East. The resultant vector from the start is towards the Northeast.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Alice starts from her home, walks 15 meters East, turns left and walks 10 meters, then turns right and walks 5 meters. What is the shortest distance between her final position and her home?
questions.explanation: Alice's movements create a path equivalent to 15 meters East and 15 meters North. Using the Pythagorean theorem, the shortest distance is √(15^2 + 15^2) = √450 = 21.21 meters, approximately 22 meters.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: David walks 20 meters North, turns 45° right and walks 20√2 meters, then turns left and walks 20 meters. In which direction is he now from the starting point?
questions.explanation: David's path takes him 20 meters North, then 20 meters Northeast (after turning 45° right), and then 20 meters further East. His final position is in the Northeast direction relative to the start.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Emma walks 30 meters East, turns 135° left and walks 50 meters, then turns right 90° and walks 40 meters. What is the final position of Emma with respect to her starting point?
questions.explanation: Emma's movements result in: 30 meters East, then 50 meters at 135° from East results in moving 35 meters West and 35 meters North. Then a right 90° and moving 40 meters results in 40 meters North. The net result from the start: 40 meters North, 20 meters West.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Nina walks 40 meters South, turns right and walks 40 meters, then takes a left turn and walks 20 meters, then turns 135° right and walks 20√2 meters. How far is she from the starting point?
questions.explanation: Nina's movements result in: 40 meters South, 40 meters West, 20 meters South, and 20 meters Northwest. The final calculation gives her position 50 meters away from the start using a straight-line distance calculation.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Alex walks 12 meters North, then 8 meters East. What is the final direction from the starting point?
questions.explanation: Starting from the origin, Alex moves 12m North (Y-coordinate becomes 12) and 8m East (X-coordinate becomes 8). Using the coordinate (8, 12), the direction from the origin is Northeast as both X and Y components are positive.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Jamie travels 15 meters South, turns left and walks 20 meters, then turns right and walks 10 meters. What is the shortest distance from the starting point?
questions.explanation: Starting at the origin, Jamie moves 15m South, left turn to East 20m, then right turn to South 10m. Final position: (20, -25). Using Pythagorean theorem: √(20^2 + 25^2) = √1025 ≈ 25 meters.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Sara walks 30 meters East, then 24 meters South, turns 45° left and walks 14 meters. What is her final direction from the starting point?
questions.explanation: Sara moves from (0,0) to (30,0), then to (30,-24). A 45° left turn from South points to Southwest. Moving 14m results in a southwest direction from the origin.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Charlie starts from point A, walks 40 meters North, then turns 135° right and walks 50 meters, then turns 45° left and continues for 30 meters. What is the net displacement from point A?
questions.explanation: Initial North move to (0,40), 135° right turn results in -x, -y component. After 50m in SE direction and another 45° left, the final vector calculation results in ≈ 85.35m using combined vector paths.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Dana walks 60 meters East, then takes a 90° left turn and walks 25 meters, then takes another 90° left turn and walks 60 meters, then finally takes a 90° left turn and walks 25 meters. How far and in which direction is she from her starting point?
questions.explanation: Dana's movement forms a rectangle and returns to her starting point after completing a full loop: (60, 0) -> (60, 25) -> (0, 25) -> (0, 0). She is back at the starting point with zero displacement.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A person starts walking from point A and goes 10 meters North, then 15 meters East, and finally 5 meters South. What is the shortest distance from the starting point?
questions.explanation: The person moves 10m North and 5m South, resulting in a net movement of 5m North. They also move 15m East. Using Pythagorean theorem, the shortest distance is the hypotenuse: √(5^2 + 15^2) = √250 = 15.81 meters, approximately 16 meters, but the closest whole number option is 13 meters which rounds the initial calculation differently, given the choices.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Lisa starts walking from her house. She walks 12 meters East, takes a 90° turn to her right and walks 16 meters. Then, she turns 45° to her left and walks 10 meters. In which direction is she now facing?
questions.explanation: Lisa starts by going East, turns right to face South, then takes a 45° left turn resulting in facing Southeast.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Rahul walks 30 meters North, then turns left and walks 25 meters. He turns left again, walks 30 meters and finally turns right and walks 10 meters. How far is he from the starting point?
questions.explanation: Rahul returns to the same north-south line after moving 30 meters North, then South again 30 meters. He is left with only the Eastward movement: 25 meters. The final right turn does not affect the distance to start point significantly due to directionality of options.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A person starts from a point and moves 50 meters towards the South. He then turns left and walks 40 meters. After that, he turns left and walks 60 meters. Finally, he turns left and walks 40 meters. How far is he from the starting point now?
questions.explanation: The person makes a rectangular path with the final movements opposite to the first 50 meters South, bringing him 10 meters away from the start point: (50m - 60m) = 10 meters in the North-South direction.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Starting from her office, Sarah walked 30 meters West, then turned left and walked 40 meters. She turned left again and walked 50 meters. Next, she turned right and walked 10 meters. If she finally turns left and walks 30 meters, how far and in which direction is she from her office?
questions.explanation: Sarah's final position is calculated by resolving the individual movements: she moves to a net position of 20 meters North from her starting point, factoring in all directional changes.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: John starts from his house and walks 10 meters North, then 15 meters East. Finally, he walks 5 meters South. In which direction is he from his starting point?
questions.explanation: Starting at (0, 0), John walks 10 meters North to (0, 10), then 15 meters East to (15, 10), and finally 5 meters South to (15, 5). His net direction is Northeast from the starting point.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Sarah walks 30 meters North and then turns right to walk 20 meters. She turns right again and walks 10 meters. After turning left, she walks 25 meters. What is her final position relative to the starting point?
questions.explanation: Sarah starts at (0, 0), moves to (0, 30), turns right to (20, 30), turns right again to (20, 20), then turns left and moves to (20, 45). She is 15 meters North of the starting point.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Emily starts at point A and walks 40 meters East, then turns 45° to her right and walks 30 meters. She makes another 45° right turn and walks 50 meters. How far is she from the starting point?
questions.explanation: Emily's path forms a triangle with her movements. Using the law of cosines to calculate the distance from the starting point, the calculation results in approximately 60 meters.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Starting at point X, Tom walks 25 meters South, then 15 meters West. He turns 90° left and walks 40 meters, then makes a 135° right turn and walks 30 meters. If Tom wants to return to point X, how far and in which direction should he walk?
questions.explanation: Calculating the net displacement of Tom's journey results in a requirement for a 50-meter walk Northeast to return to the starting point.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A cyclist starts at point O and rides 50 meters North, then turns 120° left and travels 60 meters. They then turn 90° right and ride another 40 meters. What is the final bearing of the cyclist from the starting point?
questions.explanation: The final position and orientation from point O, calculated using vector geometry, places the cyclist at a bearing of 60° North of East.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Ravi starts walking from his house and walks 10 meters North. He then walks 15 meters East, followed by 5 meters South. What is his final direction from the starting point?
questions.explanation: Starting point is at (0,0). Ravi moves 10m North to (0,10), then 15m East to (15,10), and finally 5m South to (15,5). To find the final direction from the origin, draw a line from (0,0) to (15,5). The line points towards Northeast direction.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Aman starts walking 20 meters South and then turns left to walk 30 meters. He then turns right and walks 10 meters, turns right again to walk 30 meters. What is the shortest distance from his starting point?
questions.explanation: Aman's movements bring him to: (0,-20) -> (-30,-20) -> (-30,-10) -> (0,-10). The shortest distance from starting point (0,0) to (0,-10) is 30 meters, directly downward (South).
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Sara starts from point A and walks 12 meters East, then 5 meters North, followed by 8 meters West. She turns right and walks 6 meters. In which direction and how far is she from point A?
questions.explanation: Sara's path is: (0,0) -> (12,0) -> (12,5) -> (4,5) -> (4,11). From starting point (0,0) to (4,11), her East component is 4, North component is 11. Net distance is calculated using Pythagorean theorem: √(4^2 + 11^2) ≈ 9 meters East.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Manoj starts walking from his home and walks 40 meters East. Then he turns left and walks 30 meters. He takes a right turn and walks 50 meters, then turns left and walks 30 meters, and finally takes another left to walk 20 meters. How far is Manoj from his starting point?
questions.explanation: Manoj's path: (0,0) -> (40,0) -> (40,30) -> (90,30) -> (90,0) -> (70,0). Final position (70,0). Distance from start (0,0) to (70,0) is 70 meters.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Rina walks 30 meters North, then 40 meters in the direction 45° East of North. She then turns 90° clockwise and walks 50 meters. How far is she from the starting point?
questions.explanation: Starting point is (0,0). After 30m North: (0,30). 40m 45° East of North leads to (28.28, 58.28). Turning 90° clockwise (towards East) and moving 50m leads to (78.28, 58.28). Using Pythagorean theorem, distance from origin: √((78.28)^2 + (58.28)^2) ≈ 90 meters.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
There are six floors in a building numbered 1 to 6, with six people: A, B, C, D, E, and F living on different floors, one on each floor. The following conditions are known:
1. A lives on an even-numbered floor.
2. B lives immediately above C.
3. D lives on the topmost floor.
4. E does not live on the floor immediately below D.
5. F lives two floors below B.
Who lives on the second floor?
questions.explanation:
1. Since D is on the topmost floor (Floor 6), and E does not live immediately below D, E cannot be on Floor 5.
2. A must live on an even-numbered floor, so A must be on either Floor 2 or Floor 4.
3. B lives immediately above C, which means if C is on Floor 1, B is on Floor 2, and F then must be on Floor 4.
4. Since A must be on an even-numbered floor, A is on Floor 2 and thus C cannot be on Floor 1.
5. Therefore, C must be on Floor 2, B on Floor 3, and F on Floor 5.
6. Therefore, E must live on Floor 1.
So the final arrangement is: E - Floor 1, C - Floor 2, B - Floor 3, A - Floor 4, F - Floor 5, D - Floor 6. The person on the second floor is C.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
There are seven floors in a building numbered 1 to 7. Each floor is occupied by one of the seven friends: P, Q, R, S, T, U, and V. The following conditions apply:
1. P lives on the fifth floor.
2. T lives on an even-numbered floor below P.
3. There is one floor between Q and R, with Q living above R.
4. S lives immediately below V.
5. U lives two floors above T.
Which floor does Q live on?
questions.explanation:
1. With P on Floor 5, T must be on either Floor 2 or Floor 4 (since T is on an even-numbered floor below P).
2. If T is on Floor 2, U is on Floor 4, which leaves Floor 3 open for either Q or R, but violates the condition since one floor must be between them.
3. Therefore, T must be on Floor 4, making U on Floor 6.
4. Q and R must then be on Floors 3 and 1 respectively to maintain one floor between them.
5. The remaining Floors 2 and 7 are occupied by S and V, with S below V, so S is on Floor 2 and V on Floor 3.
6. Final arrangement: R - Floor 1, S - Floor 2, V - Floor 3, T - Floor 4, P - Floor 5, U - Floor 6, Q - Floor 7.
Q is on Floor 6.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
A building has eight floors and eight different items placed one on each floor: Bicycle, Kite, Laptop, Mobile, Notebook, Pen, Book, and Tablet. The conditions are:
1. The Kite is on the third floor.
2. The Tablet is two floors above the Bicycle.
3. The Pen is neither on an odd-numbered floor nor adjacent to the Laptop.
4. The Mobile is on a floor below the Notebook and above the Book.
5. The Tablet is not on the topmost floor.
6. The Book is on the first floor.
What item is placed on the fifth floor?
questions.explanation:
1. Since the Tablet is two floors above the Bicycle and not on the topmost floor, the Tablet can be on Floor 7 or Floor 6, placing the Bicycle on Floor 5 or Floor 4 respectively.
2. The Kite is fixed on Floor 3.
3. The Book is on Floor 1.
4. The Mobile must be above the Book but below the Notebook; the only possible places for the Mobile are Floors 2 or 4. If Mobile is on Floor 4, Notebook can be on Floor 6.
5. Since the Pen is not on odd-numbered floors, it can be on Floor 2 or Floor 8. With Mobile on 4 and Tablet on 6, Pen can be on 8.
6. Therefore, the final arrangement: Book - Floor 1, Pen - Floor 2, Kite - Floor 3, Mobile - Floor 4, Bicycle - Floor 5, Notebook - Floor 6, Tablet - Floor 7, Laptop - Floor 8.
The fifth floor has the Bicycle.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
In a building with nine floors, nine people A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, and I are living, each on a different floor. The following conditions are known:
1. A lives on the topmost floor.
2. F lives on the lowest floor.
3. C lives on an even-numbered floor.
4. There are three floors between D and H.
5. E lives immediately above G.
6. There are two floors between B and I, with B living above I.
7. D does not live on the fourth floor.
Who lives on the seventh floor?
questions.explanation:
1. A is on Floor 9, F is on Floor 1.
2. C must be on an even-numbered floor: 2, 4, 6, or 8.
3. If D and H are separated by three floors, possible pairs are (D - 5, H - 1) or (D - 9, H - 5) or (D - 6, H - 2) etc.
4. E immediately above G places E/G pairs on (9/8), (8/7), etc., but E cannot be on 9.
5. Considering all conditions, D is most logically placed on Floor 7 (as placing D on another floor either violates a condition or leads to multiple possible arrangements).
6. With E/G pair logic and separation of B and I, possible configurations are solved further to verify D must be on Floor 7.
Thus, D lives on the seventh floor.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
In a building with 10 floors, 10 people: A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I, and J are living, each on a different floor. The following conditions apply:
1. A lives on the fourth floor.
2. B lives on a floor above E but below C.
3. D lives on an odd-numbered floor but not the first.
4. G is on a floor immediately below F.
5. H is exactly three floors below J.
6. I lives on a floor above G but below B.
7. E is not on the second floor.
Which floor does J live on?
questions.explanation:
1. With A on Floor 4, conditions guide E not on Floor 2, so possible placements are E (Floor 3, 5, 6).
2. B must be above E but below C, placing B within the range not possible on Floors 1, 4, or 10.
3. D on odd floor not 1 is Floors 3, 5, 7, or 9.
4. G and F are consecutive, F has to be higher than G.
5. J is three floors above H, placing pairs on Floors 1/4, 2/5, 3/6.
6. Final configurations after analyzing all possibilities lead to H - Floor 6, J - Floor 9.
Thus, J lives on the ninth floor.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: There is a building with 5 floors (numbered 1 to 5 from bottom to top). Five people: John, Mike, Sarah, Anna, and Paul live on different floors of this building, with one person per floor. The following conditions are given: 1) Mike lives on the topmost floor. 2) Sarah lives on an even-numbered floor. 3) John lives on a floor immediately below Anna's floor. 4) Paul lives on the first floor. Who lives on the fourth floor?
questions.explanation: Paul is on the 1st floor as per the condition. Mike is on the 5th floor. Sarah must be on the 2nd or 4th floor since she lives on an even-numbered floor. If Sarah is on the 2nd floor, Anna can only be on the 4th, making John on the 3rd floor. Thus, Anna lives on the 4th floor.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a building with 7 floors (numbered 1 to 7 from bottom to top), seven friends: George, Henry, Irene, Jessica, Kevin, Linda, and Monica live on different floors. Consider the following clues: 1) Monica lives on the third floor. 2) There are exactly two floors between Jessica and Kevin. 3) Irene lives immediately above Linda. 4) Kevin lives on a floor immediately below George. 5) Henry lives on the top floor. 6) Linda lives on the second floor. Who lives on the sixth floor?
questions.explanation: Linda on the 2nd floor implies Irene is on the 3rd floor. Monica is on the 3rd, so Monica and Irene can’t share the 3rd floor. This means Irene must be on the 6th floor. Kevin must be on the 4th floor, making George on the 5th. Jessica would then be on the 7th floor since there are two floors between her and Kevin.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A building has 8 floors (numbered 1 to 8 from bottom to top), and each floor is occupied by one person among Adam, Brian, Charles, David, Edward, Frank, Gary, and Harry. The following conditions are given: 1) Adam lives on a floor immediately above David. 2) Frank lives on an even-numbered floor. 3) Brian lives on a floor that is exactly two floors above Gary's floor. 4) Harry does not live on an adjacent floor to Charles. 5) Gary lives below Frank. 6) Edward lives on the top floor. Which floor does Charles live on?
questions.explanation: Edward on the 8th floor. Frank must be on floors 2, 4, or 6 due to even-numbered constraint and Gary below him. Brian is two floors above Gary, implying possible placements for Gary on 1 and 2. Charles cannot be adjacent to Harry. After evaluating conditions, Charles fits best on the 4th floor.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: There are two buildings, each with 5 floors (numbered 1 to 5 from bottom to top). Ten friends: Alex, Bob, Clara, Dan, Eve, Fiona, Greg, Helen, Isaac, and Jenny are to be arranged in these buildings such that: 1) Alex and Clara live in different buildings but on the same floor. 2) Bob lives two floors above Eve. 3) Dan lives in the same building as Bob. 4) Greg does not live on the ground floor. 5) Fiona and Jenny live on the top floor but in different buildings. 6) Helen lives on the floor below Isaac. 7) Isaac lives in the same building as Alex. Who lives on the third floor of building 1?
questions.explanation: Fiona and Jenny occupy the top floors. Alex's placement determines the setup of building 1 floors as Alex is with Isaac. Dan must be with Bob since they share the building. Greg does not live on the ground floor, leaving him for 3rd floor of building 1 after checking other conditions.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a 9-floor building, each floor is occupied by one person out of the following: Alicia, Brian, Cheryl, Diana, Ethan, Fiona, George, Hannah, and Ivan. Consider these conditions: 1) Diana lives three floors above Alicia. 2) Ethan lives immediately below Cheryl. 3) Brian lives on a floor between Cheryl and Alicia. 4) George is not on an adjacent floor to Diana. 5) Hannah lives on the 5th floor. 6) Ivan lives two floors below Fiona. 7) Fiona lives on the top floor. Who lives on the 8th floor?
questions.explanation: Fiona on the 9th floor. Ivan thus on the 7th. Diana is placed to keep George non-adjacent. Alicia must be 3 floors below Diana, making her floor 2. Ethan and Cheryl's condition places Cheryl on floor 6 and Ethan on floor 5. Brian fits on the 8th floor due to space left.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: There is a building with 5 floors and 5 people: A, B, C, D, and E, each living on different floors. Consider these conditions: 1) A lives on the second floor. 2) B lives immediately above E. 3) C lives two floors above D. 4) E does not live on the ground floor. Which floor does D live on?
questions.explanation: The conditions give: A on 2nd floor, E not on ground floor, B immediately above E, and C two floors above D. We place A on floor 2. Since E is not on the ground floor, E must be on floor 3, and B on floor 4. C must be on floor 5, meaning D must be on floor 1.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A building has 7 floors numbered 1 to 7 from bottom to top. Seven people: G, H, I, J, K, L, and M, live on different floors. Consider these conditions: 1) G lives on an odd-numbered floor below floor 5. 2) M lives exactly two floors above L. 3) J lives on the top floor. 4) H lives on an even-numbered floor, but not the 6th. 5) K lives immediately below H. Which floor does M live on?
questions.explanation: From the conditions: G on 1st or 3rd floor, but only 3rd is left because J is on 7th. H can be on 2nd or 4th; if on 2nd, K on 1st, leaving no room for G, so H must be on 4th, K on 3rd, G on 1st. M is two floors above L; placing M on 6th and L on 4th satisfies all conditions.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A building with 8 floors is home to 8 people: P, Q, R, S, T, U, V, and W, each on a different floor. Consider these conditions: 1) S lives on an odd-numbered floor. 2) P is two floors below S. 3) V lives on a floor above T. 4) Q lives immediately above W. 5) R lives immediately below S. 6) U is not on the 8th floor and lives above T. Which floor does P live on?
questions.explanation: S must be on an odd floor. If S is on 5th, R on 4th, P must be on 3rd (2 floors below S). W and Q must be on the 1st and 2nd floors. V and U are above T; if U is not on 8th, place U on 6th, T on 7th, and V on 8th.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a building with 10 floors, there are 10 items labeled A to J, each placed on a separate floor. Consider these conditions: 1) A is not on the 1st or 10th floor. 2) B is on an even-numbered floor below 6. 3) C is placed three floors above D. 4) E is two floors below F. 5) G is directly below H. 6) I is neither on an odd-numbered floor nor on the top floor. 7) J is on the 5th floor. Which floor is item E on?
questions.explanation: J is on floor 5. B on 2nd or 4th. If B is on 2nd, F can be on 5th or 7th, but 5th is J, so F on 7th, E on 5th, which conflicts. B must be on 4th. F on 6th, E on 4th. G below H means G on 3rd, H on 4th. I is on 2nd floor (even, not top), leaving C on 8th and D on 5th.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Two adjacent buildings, X and Y, each have 5 floors. Five people, K, L, M, N, and O, live in building X, and five items, P, Q, R, S, and T, are placed on the floors of building Y. Consider these conditions: 1) K is on a higher floor than M. 2) N is two floors below L. 3) O is not on the top floor. 4) P is directly below Q. 5) R is placed two floors above S. 6) T is not on the ground floor. 7) K's floor number equals the sum of the floor numbers of R and S. Which floor is M on in building X?
questions.explanation: Assuming K is on 5th, then R and S must be on 2nd and 3rd (or reverse) to satisfy sum condition, with Q on 1st and P on 2nd. If O is on 4th, L on 3rd, N on 1st, leaving M on 2nd.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: There are 5 floors in a building numbered 1 to 5 from bottom to top. Five people: Alice, Bob, Charlie, Diana, and Eve are living on different floors. The following conditions are given: 1) Alice lives on the top floor. 2) Bob lives on a floor above Charlie. 3) Diana does not live on floor 2. 4) Eve lives immediately below Bob. Who lives on floor 3?
questions.explanation: Alice lives on floor 5. Bob must be on floor 4 as Eve lives immediately below him on floor 3. Charlie cannot be above Bob, so he is on floor 2. Thus, Diana is on floor 3.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In an 8-floor building, floors are numbered 1 through 8 from bottom to top. Seven people - A, B, C, D, E, F, and G - live on different floors, with one floor remaining vacant. The following conditions are given: 1) C lives on the floor immediately above A. 2) B lives two floors above D. 3) There are two floors between G and E. 4) F does not live on the top floor. 5) A does not live on the bottom floor. Which floor is vacant?
questions.explanation: Given that C is immediately above A, they occupy consecutive floors. B being two floors above D, means if D is on floor 1, B is on floor 3. G and E are separated by two floors; if E is on floor 4, G is on floor 7. F cannot be on the top floor, placing them on floor 8. Therefore, floors 2, 5, or 6 must be vacant. Since A cannot be on the bottom floor and logically deducing from placements, A is on floor 6 and C on floor 7, leaving floor 2 vacant.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A building has 7 floors. Seven people: J, K, L, M, N, O, and P live on different floors of the building. The following conditions are given: 1) J does not live on the first or the last floor. 2) N lives immediately above J. 3) O lives on an even-numbered floor. 4) There are two floors between M and P. 5) K lives above M but below P. On which floor does K live?
questions.explanation: J cannot be on the 1st or 7th floor. Placing J on floor 2 results in N on floor 3. M and P are 2 floors apart: M on 1, P on 4, or M on 2, P on 5. K is above M and below P, thus if P is on 4, M is on 1, K must be on 3. Therefore, J is on 4, N on 5, and K on floor 5 is ruled out; thus, K is on floor 3.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a 9-floor building numbered 1 to 9 from bottom to top, nine friends live on different floors. The following conditions are given: 1) L is on an odd-numbered floor below M. 2) N lives three floors above O. 3) P lives between L and O. 4) Q lives on an even-numbered floor above R. 5) There are two floors between N and R. 6) S lives on a floor above T and next to Q. Which floor does R live on?
questions.explanation: N being three floors above O suggests O on 1 and N on 4, or O on 2 and N on 5, etc. P is between L and O, thus possibilities begin to take shape. As Q is above R on an even floor, if R is on 3, Q is on 4 or 5. From 2 floors between N and R, if R is on 5, N should be on 7 but it contradicts N's position related to O. Correct deduction places R on floor 5.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: There are 10 floors in a building numbered 1 to 10 from bottom to top. Ten people: X, Y, Z, U, V, W, A, B, C, and D live on different floors. The following conditions are given: 1) X lives on the top floor. 2) Y lives three floors below Z. 3) W lives immediately above V. 4) There are two floors between U and Z. 5) A lives on an even-numbered floor below D. 6) C lives immediately above B but below A. 7) There are three floors between V and B. Which floor does D live on?
questions.explanation: X is on floor 10. Y is three floors below Z, placing them if Z is on floor 8, Y is on 5, etc. W is above V, thus if V is on floor 3, W is on 4. U and Z need two floors apart, and placing Z on 8 and U on 6 fits. A is on even floor below D; C is above B but below A. With three floors between V and B, placing B on floor 1, C on 2, A on 4, and D on 9 completes the configuration.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: There are 5 floors in a building, numbered 1 to 5. Each floor is occupied by a different person: Alan, Ben, Carol, Dan, and Eva. The following conditions apply: 1) Ben lives on floor 2. 2) Carol lives immediately above Ben. 3) Eva lives on floor 5. 4) Alan does not live on floor 1. Who lives on floor 3?
questions.explanation: From the conditions: Ben is on floor 2, Carol is on floor 3 (immediately above Ben), Eva is on floor 5. Alan cannot be on floor 1, so Dan must be on floor 1. Therefore, Alan is on floor 4.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: There are 7 floors in a building, numbered from 1 to 7. Each floor is occupied by a different person: P, Q, R, S, T, U, and V. The following conditions apply: 1) T lives on an odd-numbered floor. 2) Q lives immediately above P. 3) U lives two floors above S. 4) R lives on the top floor. 5) V lives on floor 5. Who lives on floor 3?
questions.explanation: R lives on floor 7. V is on floor 5. Since Q is immediately above P, either floors 1 and 2 or 3 and 4 must be occupied by P and Q. U is two floors above S, so floors 2 and 4 or 3 and 5 might initially seem possible. Given V occupies floor 5, S must be on floor 2, and U on floor 4. The remaining arrangement that fits all constraints has P on floor 3 and Q on floor 4.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A building has 8 floors, numbered 1 to 8. Each floor is occupied by a different person: Alex, Bob, Cathy, David, Eva, Frank, Gina, and Helen. The following conditions apply: 1) David lives on the top floor. 2) Eva lives on the floor immediately below Cathy. 3) Alex lives three floors below Gina. 4) Bob lives on an even-numbered floor. 5) Helen lives above Frank but below Cathy. 6) Gina lives on floor 7. On which floor does Alex live?
questions.explanation: Gina is on floor 7, so Alex is on floor 4. David is on floor 8. Helen must be on floor 5 or 6; Cathy can't be on floor 8, 7, or 5 due to positioning. Eva then must be on floor 2, placing Cathy on floor 3. Helen can only be on floor 5, so Frank is on floor 6, Bob on floor 2. Alex on floor 3 fits the remaining positions.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A building has 9 floors, numbered 1 to 9. Each floor is occupied by a different person: M, N, O, P, Q, R, S, T, and U. The following conditions apply: 1) S lives on an odd-numbered floor. 2) N lives three floors above T. 3) O lives on an even-numbered floor and immediately below U. 4) R lives on floor 8. 5) M lives below Q. 6) P lives between N and T. 7) U does not live on the top floor. 8) T is not on floor 1. Where does S live?
questions.explanation: R is on floor 8, so U cannot be on floor 9 and must be on floor 4, making O on floor 3. N must be on floor 7, so T is on floor 4 and P on floor 6. M must be on floor 2, with Q on floor 5. Therefore, S, who is on an odd floor, can only be on floor 1, 5, or 9, but 5 is unoccupied.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a building with 10 floors, numbered 1 to 10, each floor is occupied by a different person: A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I, J. The following conditions apply: 1) A lives on floor 1. 2) B lives on a floor higher than E. 3) D lives three floors above C. 4) F lives on an even floor and directly above G. 5) H lives on floor 10. 6) I lives below E but above J. 7) C does not live on floor 2 or 5. Who lives on floor 6?
questions.explanation: H is on floor 10, so C must be on floor 3 for D on floor 6. F must be on floor 8 since F is above G who is on floor 7. A is on floor 1, and C is confirmed on floor 3. I is below E, who is below B, and I above J, so J on floor 2, I on floor 4, E on floor 5, and B on floor 9. Therefore, F lives on floor 6.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: There is a 5-floor building with floors numbered 1 to 5 from bottom to top. Five people, A, B, C, D, and E, live on different floors. The following conditions are known: 1) A lives on the third floor. 2) B lives immediately above E. 3) C lives on the top floor. 4) D lives immediately below B. Who lives on the first floor?
questions.explanation: Step-by-step solution: A lives on the third floor. C lives on the fifth floor (top floor). Since B lives immediately above E, and D lives immediately below B, B must live on the fourth floor, E on the first floor, and D on the second floor. Hence, E lives on the first floor.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a 7-floor building, numbered 1 to 7 from bottom to top, there are 7 people: P, Q, R, S, T, U, and V, each living on a different floor. The following information is known: 1) Q lives on the fourth floor. 2) S lives on a floor immediately below U. 3) P lives on the top floor. 4) T lives on the first floor. 5) V lives two floors above R. On which floor does S live?
questions.explanation: P lives on the seventh floor. T lives on the first floor. Q is on the fourth floor. V must live on the sixth floor as he lives two floors above R, who is on the fourth floor. U cannot be on the seventh or fourth floor, so U is on the fifth floor, making S on the third floor. S lives on the third floor.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In an 8-floor building (floors 1 to 8), eight people: A, B, C, D, E, F, G, and H live on different floors. The clues are as follows: 1) A lives three floors above E. 2) B lives immediately below G. 3) F lives on an even-numbered floor. 4) D lives immediately above H. 5) C lives on the top floor. 6) Neither B nor D lives on the second floor. On which floor does F live?
questions.explanation: C is on the eighth floor. A lives three floors above E, possibilities are A/E: 4/1, 5/2, 6/3. B and G are adjacent, leaving B on the third floor and G on the fourth. D above H means D is on the second floor and H on the first floor. F is left to fit on the fourth floor (even-numbered), which satisfies all conditions.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a 10-floor building numbered 1 to 10 from bottom to top, ten different people live: J, K, L, M, N, O, P, Q, R, and S. The following conditions apply: 1) K lives on the fifth floor. 2) P lives on an odd-numbered floor above M. 3) O lives immediately below L. 4) N lives above J. 5) R lives on the eighth floor. 6) Q and S are not adjacent. 7) J lives three floors below S, who lives on an even-numbered floor. Who lives on the second floor?
questions.explanation: K is on the fifth floor. R is on the eighth floor. S can be on the fourth or sixth floor, making J on the first or third floor, respectively. Given the non-adjacency of Q and S, and that P is above M on an odd-numbered floor, solutions align with Q on the second floor.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Consider two buildings A and B, each with floors numbered 1 to 5 from bottom to top. In building A, residents are P, Q, R, S, and T. In building B, residents are U, V, W, X, and Y. The known conditions are: 1) P lives on the same floor as W. 2) R lives immediately above Q, who lives on the second floor. 3) U lives three floors above X. 4) S lives on the top floor of Building A. 5) V and Y are not on the first floor. 6) T lives on an even-numbered floor. Where does Y live in Building B?
questions.explanation: In Building A: Q is on the second floor, R is on the third floor, and S on the fifth floor. P and W must align, and T is on the fourth floor. In Building B: U on the fourth floor, X on the first floor. V and Y on second and third floors, with neither on the first floor, placing Y on the third floor.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Statements: A > B, B > C. Which of the following is definitely true?
questions.explanation: Using transitive property: From A > B and B > C, it follows that A > C.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statements: P > Q, R < S, Q > T. Which conclusion(s) follow?
I. P > T
II. R = S
III. P < R
questions.explanation: From P > Q and Q > T, by transitive property, P > T. R < S and P > Q do not provide enough information to conclude R = S or P < R.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statements: X ≥ Y, Y < Z, Z ≤ W. Which conclusion(s) follow?
I. X > Z
II. Y < W
III. X ≥ W
questions.explanation: From Y < Z and Z ≤ W, Y < W. X ≥ Y and Y < Z provide insufficient data to deduce X > Z or X ≥ W directly.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statements: M ≥ N, N ≠ O, O < P, P = Q. Which conclusion(s) follow?
I. N < Q
II. M > O
III. P > N
questions.explanation: N ≠ O does not determine the relationship between N and O conclusively in comparison to Q. M ≥ N and N ≠ O do not logically support that M > O. P = Q indicates that P = Q, not necessarily that P > N.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statements: A ≥ B, B = C, C > D, D ≠ E. Which of the following is/are definitely false?
I. A < D
II. C > E
III. B = E

options.D: I and II are definitely false

questions.explanation: A ≥ B and B = C implies A ≥ C. C > D gives no information about E compared to C directly. D ≠ E only shows inequality, not enough to state C > E is false. B = C and D ≠ E indicates B = E cannot be true.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statements: P > Q, Q > R
Which of the following is definitely true?
questions.explanation: Using transitive property: P > Q and Q > R implies P > R.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statements: A > B, B ≤ C, C < D
Conclusions: I. A > D II. B < D III. A = C
Which conclusion(s) follow?
questions.explanation: From B ≤ C and C < D, we infer B < D. A > D cannot be concluded directly since A > B and B ≤ C allows for both possibilities of A being greater or equal to C, which is not directly comparable to D without more information. Similarly, A = C cannot be directly concluded.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statements: X ≥ Y, Y < Z, Z = W
Conclusions: I. X > W II. X = W III. X ≥ Z
Which conclusion(s) follow?
questions.explanation: Z = W allows substitution such that Y < W. Since X ≥ Y and Y < Z, we can derive X ≥ Z through transitivity, but X > W or X = W cannot be directly concluded.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statements: M ≤ N, N < O, O ≠ P
Which of the following is/are definitely true?
I. M < O II. N = P III. O > M
questions.explanation: From N < O and M ≤ N, we infer M < O. Also, since M ≤ N and N < O, it follows that O > M. O ≠ P does not provide enough information to conclude N = P.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statements: P > Q, Q ≥ R, S ≠ R, P = T
Which of the following is/are definitely false?
I. T < S II. Q < S III. P ≥ R
questions.explanation: P > Q and Q ≥ R allow us to infer that P > R, therefore P ≥ R is true. Since P = T, T < S cannot be determined directly because S ≠ R doesn't provide a comparison between T and S. Without additional information, Q < S and T < S can't be definitively declared false.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Statements: 1. A > B 2. B > C. Which of the following is definitely true?
questions.explanation: Using the transitive property: If A > B and B > C, then A > C is a definite conclusion.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Statements: 1. P ≥ Q 2. Q > R 3. R < S. Which conclusions are definitely true? I. P > R II. Q < S III. P ≥ S
questions.explanation: From P ≥ Q and Q > R, we have P > R (conclusion I is true). Since Q > R and R < S, we deduce Q < S (conclusion II is true). Conclusion III is uncertain as we cannot determine a definite relation between P and S from the given statements.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Statements: 1. X ≤ Y 2. Y < Z 3. Z ≥ W. Which conclusions are definitely true? I. X < Z II. Y = W III. X ≤ W
questions.explanation: Using the transitive property, from X ≤ Y and Y < Z, we deduce X < Z (I is true). From Z ≥ W and X ≤ Y with Y < Z, X ≤ W can be inferred (III is true). II is false as no equality is implied.
questions.subject: Reasoning
