A is not an immediate neighbor of C. G sits to the right of I but not at the end. E is second to the left of C. If I is seated at one of the ends, who is sitting in the middle?
questions.explanation: The order from left to right is: I, H, G, A, E, C, B, D, F. E is sitting in the middle.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Five friends are standing in a row. Each of them is wearing a different colored shirt (Red, Blue, Green, Yellow, Black) and lives on a different floor of a five-story building (1 to 5). The following conditions are given: 1. The person in the Red shirt lives on an odd-numbered floor. 2. The person in the Blue shirt stands to the immediate left of the person in the Green shirt. 3. The person on the top floor is wearing a Yellow shirt. 4. The person in the Black shirt lives below the person in the Green shirt. 5. The person in the Green shirt does not live on the 3rd floor. Who lives on the 2nd floor?
questions.explanation: From the conditions: The person in the Yellow shirt lives on the top floor (5th floor). The person in the Green shirt must be on the 4th floor because they cannot be on the 3rd floor and the Black shirt must be below Green, leaving 2nd floor for Blue. Thus, Blue is on the 2nd floor.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Six colleagues are sitting around a round table discussing a project. Each of them comes from a different department (HR, Sales, IT, Finance, Marketing, R&D) and prefers a different snack (Cookies, Sandwich, Pizza, Salad, Fruit, Chips). The following clues are given: 1. The person from HR is sitting to the immediate left of the person who likes Pizza. 2. The person who likes Chips is from Finance and sits directly opposite to the one who prefers Sandwich. 3. The IT professional sits to the right of the person who likes Salad. 4. The Marketing person is not sitting next to the one who prefers Fruit. 5. The R&D person is sitting between the IT and HR persons. Who sits to the right of the person from Sales?
questions.explanation: Using the given clues: The person from HR sits left of Pizza, Chips is with Finance and opposite Sandwich, IT is right of Salad, and R&D is between IT and HR. After placing all accordingly, the person from Marketing sits to the right of the person from Sales.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Seven players participate in a chess tournament. Each player plays one game a day for a week (Monday to Sunday) with no repetition of opponents. Each player has a different starting rank (1 to 7) and uses a unique chess piece as a lucky charm (King, Queen, Rook, Bishop, Knight, Pawn, Wizard). The following clues are given: 1. The player who started with rank 1 played against the player using the Wizard on Tuesday. 2. The Rook player played his last game on Friday. 3. The Bishop player played against the player with rank 3 on Wednesday. 4. The player with rank 7 played against the Pawn player on Thursday. 5. The Queen player did not play on Monday. 6. The player using the Knight as a lucky charm had his game against the King player on Saturday. On which day did the player with rank 5 play against the player using the Rook?
questions.explanation: Using the conditions: Rank 1 vs Wizard on Tuesday, Rank 3 vs Bishop on Wednesday, Rook on Friday, Knight vs King on Saturday. The only day left for the rank 5 vs Rook game is Wednesday.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Eight family members are attending a family dinner. Each person is from a different generation and has a different favorite dish (Pasta, Sushi, Steak, Tacos, Curry, Burger, Pizza, Salad). Additionally, each family member arrived at a different time (3 PM, 3:30 PM, 4 PM, 4:30 PM, 5 PM, 5:30 PM, 6 PM, 6:30 PM). The following facts are known: 1. The person who loves Sushi arrived immediately before the person who loves Tacos. 2. The youngest member who arrived at 5:30 PM loves Pizza. 3. The oldest member arrived at 3 PM and loves Pasta. 4. The person who arrived at 4 PM loves Burger. 5. The person who arrived at 6 PM is not the one who loves Salad. 6. The person who loves Steak arrived directly after the Curry lover. 7. The person who loves Salad arrived before 6 PM. Who loves the Salad?
questions.explanation: Based on the conditions: Pasta at 3 PM, Burger at 4 PM, Sushi followed by Tacos, Curry followed by Steak. Since Salad is before 6 PM and not 3, 3:30, 4, or 4:30 PM, it must be at 5 PM.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Ten executives from different departments (Legal, IT, HR, Marketing, Finance, Operations, Sales, R&D, Admin, Customer Service) are attending a conference. Each has a different keynote topic (AI, Blockchain, Cybersecurity, Marketing Trends, Financial Strategies, Operations Excellence, Sales Techniques, Innovation, Administration Insights, Customer Engagement), arrives on a different day (Monday through Friday, two per day), and drives a different colored car (Red, Blue, Green, Yellow, Black, White, Silver, Grey, Orange, Pink). The following information is available: 1. The IT executive who talks about Cybersecurity arrives on Tuesday in a Blue car. 2. The Sales executive who discusses Sales Techniques arrives on Friday in a Black car. 3. The Marketing executive speaks about Marketing Trends on Wednesday and drives a Red car. 4. The person with the topic of Innovation arrives on Thursday in a Silver car. 5. The HR executive arrives on the same day as the person with a Yellow car but not on Wednesday. 6. The Finance executive arrives on Monday with a White car. 7. The R&D executive who has a presentation on AI arrives on the same day as the Operations executive. 8. The Admin executive arrives in an Orange car. 9. The Legal executive talks about Blockchain but does not arrive on Monday. 10. The person with Customer Engagement arrives in a Grey car on Tuesday. 11. The person who drives a Pink car arrives on Friday. Who is the last person to arrive on Monday?
questions.explanation: Based on provided information: Finance on Monday with White, Operations shares day with R&D. Legal is not Monday. Thus, after pairing Finance and R&D, Operations is the last on Monday.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Five friends named Alex, Bob, Charlie, David, and Ethan each live on a different floor of a five-story building. The floors are numbered 1 to 5, with 5 being the top floor. Each friend owns a car of a different color: Red, Blue, Green, Yellow, and Black. Using the clues given, determine who lives on which floor and the color of their car. 1) Alex lives on an odd-numbered floor. 2) The person with the Yellow car lives directly above Alex. 3) Bob's car is Blue and he lives on the top floor. 4) Charlie lives on a higher floor than the owner of the Black car. 5) David lives on the 3rd floor. Who owns the Red car?
questions.explanation: Based on the clues: Bob is on the 5th floor with the Blue car. David is on the 3rd floor. Alex must be on either 1st or 3rd floor, but since David is on 3rd, Alex is on the 1st floor. Therefore, the Yellow car is on the 2nd floor. Since Charlie lives above the Black car owner and Ethan is the only one left to live on the 4th floor, the Black car must be on the 3rd floor with David. Thus, Ethan, on the 2nd floor with Yellow car, leaves Charlie with the Green car on the 4th floor, and Alex must have the Red car.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Seven people - Alice, Brian, Chloe, Dan, Eve, Frank, and Grace - work in different departments (HR, IT, Marketing, Finance, Operations, Sales, Support) and have different favorite fruits (Apple, Banana, Cherry, Date, Fig, Grapes, Kiwi). Using the clues given, determine the department and favorite fruit of each person. 1) Alice is in IT and loves Dates. 2) Brian works in Marketing but does not like Apples or Bananas. 3) Chloe is in Sales and her favorite fruit is Grapes. 4) Dan is in Finance. 5) Eve works in Support and prefers Cherry. 6) Frank dislikes Fig and works in HR. 7) Grace is in Operations and her favorite fruit is Kiwi.
questions.explanation: Based on the information: Alice (IT, Dates), Brian (Marketing, Kiwi), Chloe (Sales, Grapes), Dan (Finance, Banana), Eve (Support, Cherry), Frank (HR, Banana), Grace (Operations, Kiwi). Frank dislikes Fig, so his fruit must be Banana. Since Grace likes Kiwi, Brian cannot like it. Therefore, Brian's fruit can only be Fig, leaving Banana for Dan. This verifies all positions.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Six friends - Jack, Kevin, Liam, Mia, Nora, and Olivia - each own a different pet (Dog, Cat, Rabbit, Parrot, Fish, Hamster) and live in different colored houses (Red, Blue, Green, Yellow, White, Pink). Using the clues given, determine the pet owned and the color of the house of each friend. 1) Jack lives in the Blue house and does not own a Cat. 2) Kevin owns a Dog and does not live in the Green or Yellow house. 3) Liam's house is White and he owns a Rabbit. 4) Mia lives in the Pink house and owns a Fish. 5) Nora owns a Parrot and does not live in the Yellow house. 6) Olivia lives in the Green house. What pet does Olivia own?
questions.explanation: From the clues: Jack (Blue, not Cat), Kevin (Dog, not Green/Yellow), Liam (White, Rabbit), Mia (Pink, Fish), Nora (Parrot, not Yellow), Olivia (Green). Jack must have a Hamster as it can't be Cat, Dog, Rabbit, or Fish. Therefore, Olivia can only have a Hamster. Nora, owning a Parrot and not in Yellow, is in the Red house. This places Kevin in the Yellow house with his Dog.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Eight colleagues are seated around a square table, each one at a corner and mid-side, facing the center. They are each from different countries and drink different types of beverages. Using the clues given, determine the seating arrangement, their countries, and the beverage each one drinks. 1) The person from Brazil drinks Tea and sits at a corner. 2) The person from India is directly opposite to the person from Japan, who drinks Coffee. 3) The person from China drinks Juice and is to the left of the German. 4) The Canadian, who sits at a corner, drinks Milk. 5) The person from France is directly opposite the person who drinks Water. 6) The person drinking Soda is to the immediate left of the American. 7) The Italian is not sitting at any corner. 8) The Australian is directly opposite the person from China. Who drinks Soda?
questions.explanation: The seating is solved by placing the countries based on direct opposites and left/right positional clues. Brazilian (Tea, corner) opposite Chinese (Juice), then German, followed by Japan (Coffee). American is left to Soda drinker. After other placements, Indian drinks Soda, left of American.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Ten runners are participating in a marathon. They come from different countries (USA, UK, Japan, India, Brazil, China, Germany, France, Italy, Canada) and have different favorite numbers (1 to 10). Clues: 1) The runner from USA likes an odd number and is ahead of the one from Germany. 2) The Canadian is at an even position and likes number 8. 3) The Japanese runner is immediately ahead of the Indian. 4) The Italian, liking number 5, is three places behind the French who likes number 7. 5) The runner from Brazil is neither first nor last, liking the number 1. 6) Number 9 is liked by the runner who is at position 4. 7) The Chinese runner is after the one who likes number 2. 8) The one from UK is immediately behind the runner who likes number 6. Who is last?
questions.explanation: Through deduction from the clues: The USA runner (odd number, not last) must be ahead of Germany. Canada (8) at position 4. Japan ahead of India directly. Brazil (1) in a middle spot. Italy (5) three behind France (7). Based on other positions, the German is the only logical runner for the last position.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Five friends are seated in a row. Each of them is wearing a different colored shirt and has a favorite fruit. Determine the arrangement based on the following clues: 1. Alex is wearing a blue shirt and is sitting next to the person who likes apples. 2. The person wearing a green shirt is at one of the ends. 3. Charlie is sitting to the left of the person who likes bananas, and they are not sitting together. 4. The person wearing a red shirt likes oranges and is sitting between Alex and Charlie. 5. Bob likes grapes and is not sitting at either end. What is the color of the shirt worn by the person who likes mangoes?
questions.explanation: Following the clues, the arrangement from left to right is: Person 1 - Green shirt, apples; Person 2 - Blue shirt (Alex), grapes (Bob); Person 3 - Red shirt, oranges; Person 4 - White shirt, mangoes; Person 5 - Yellow shirt, bananas. Therefore, the person who likes mangoes is wearing a White shirt.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Seven people (L, M, N, O, P, Q, and R) are sitting in a row, facing north. Each person has a different profession: Doctor, Engineer, Teacher, Artist, Chef, Lawyer, and Scientist. Determine their seating arrangement based on these clues: 1. N is sitting third to the left of the Scientist. 2. O is not a Doctor and is second from the right end. 3. The Teacher is sitting between the Engineer and Lawyer. 4. R is a Lawyer and is sitting at one of the ends. 5. Q is second to the left of the Chef. 6. L is the Doctor and is not sitting next to the Engineer. 7. M is third to the right of P. Who is the Teacher?
questions.explanation: The seating order is R (Lawyer), L (Doctor), Q (Artist), M (Engineer), P (Teacher), N (Scientist), O (Chef). Therefore, P is the Teacher.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Six family members P, Q, R, S, T, and U are seated around a circular table. Each one is wearing a different color shirt: red, green, blue, yellow, pink, and white. Determine who is wearing which color based on the following clues: 1. P is seated between the person wearing green and the person wearing red. 2. The person wearing yellow is to the immediate right of R. 3. T is seated opposite to the person wearing the blue shirt. 4. U is not wearing the pink shirt and is sitting between S and the person wearing the white shirt. 5. S is wearing the yellow shirt. Who is wearing the green shirt?
questions.explanation: The seating arrangement around the table is as follows: P (Red), Q (Green), R (Pink), S (Yellow), T (White), U (Blue). Therefore, Q is wearing the green shirt.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Nine people (A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, and I) work in a company and occupy different floors of a building (1 to 9, not necessarily in the same order). Each person has a different car color and a unique workday. Determine the floor arrangement based on the following clues: 1. The person who works on Monday occupies the 5th floor. 2. A lives two floors above the person with a white car and works one day before the person on Friday. 3. C, who has a red car, occupies the 7th floor. 4. The person on the 1st floor works immediately after the one with a blue car. 5. G occupies the 3rd floor and works on Wednesday. 6. The person with a black car lives on the 9th floor. 7. I, with a green car, works two days after the person on the 4th floor. 8. E works on Tuesday and has a yellow car. 9. F lives two floors below B, who works on Thursday.
questions.explanation: The complete arrangement is: 1 - H, blue, Thursday; 2 - D, pink, Monday; 3 - G, orange, Wednesday; 4 - B, purple, Friday; 5 - A, grey, Tuesday; 6 - F, white, Saturday; 7 - C, red, Sunday; 8 - I, green, Monday; 9 - E, yellow, Tuesday. Therefore, A works on Tuesday with the grey car.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Ten colleagues (J, K, L, M, N, O, P, Q, R, S) each belong to different departments and have unique hobbies and favorite foods. Their offices are on floors numbered 1 to 10. Determine each person's complete profile using the clues: 1. The person whose hobby is gardening is on floor 5 and loves Italian food. 2. J is one floor above the one who enjoys painting and is in the Finance department. 3. The IT department is between the Marketing and HR on consecutive floors. 4. K, who loves Chinese food, is two floors below the person who enjoys surfing. 5. The Chef is on the top floor, right above the Auditor. 6. L, who is in the Sales department, loves Mexican food and is two floors above the person whose hobby is reading. 7. M is in the HR department, three floors above the person who loves Indian food. 8. P enjoys hiking and has their office on the floor immediately above the person in the IT department. 9. S, in the Marketing department, loves Thai food and is one floor above Q, who enjoys dancing.
questions.explanation: The arrangement is: Floor 1: Q, dancing, Finance; Floor 2: S, Thai, Marketing; Floor 3: P, hiking, IT; Floor 4: N, reading, HR; Floor 5: R, gardening, Italian; Floor 6: L, Mexican, Sales; Floor 7: K, Chinese, R&D; Floor 8: J, surfing, Legal; Floor 9: O, painting, Admin; Floor 10: M, Chef, Indian. Therefore, L loves Mexican food and is in Sales.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
There are five friends: Anne, Bob, Carl, Diane, and Ed. They each live on a different floor of a five-story building (1st to 5th floor). Each of them has a different favorite fruit: Apple, Banana, Cherry, Date, and Elderberry. Using the clues below, determine who lives on which floor and their favorite fruit. 

1. Anne lives two floors above the person whose favorite fruit is Apple.
2. The person on the 1st floor loves Cherry.
3. Bob lives on an odd-numbered floor.
4. The person whose favorite fruit is Banana lives on the 5th floor.
5. Diane lives on the floor immediately above Bob's.
6. Ed lives two floors below the person whose favorite fruit is Elderberry.

Who lives on the 2nd floor and what is their favorite fruit?
questions.explanation:
1. Since Anne lives two floors above the person who likes Apple, and Ed lives two floors below the person who likes Elderberry, we have:
   - Anne can't live on 1st or 2nd floor.
   - Elderberry can't be on the 1st or 2nd floor.
2. The person on the 1st floor likes Cherry.
3. The person with Banana is on the 5th floor.
4. Bob lives on an odd floor and Diane lives immediately above Bob, meaning Bob lives on the 3rd floor and Diane on the 4th.
5. Anne can't be on the 1st or 3rd floors, so Anne must be on the 5th floor with Banana.
6. Thus, the Apple lover is on the 3rd floor.
7. Ed on the 2nd floor means Elderberry on the 4th floor.
8. Carl is the only person left for the 2nd floor and likes Date.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Six friends — George, Helen, Ian, Jack, Karen, and Liam — each have a different profession: Architect, Doctor, Engineer, Lawyer, Teacher, and Chef. They each work on a different day of the week, Monday through Saturday. Use the clues to determine each person's profession and the day they work. 

1. George works on Monday but is not the Engineer or Lawyer.
2. The Architect works one day before the Teacher.
3. Ian works the day after Helen, who is the Doctor.
4. The Lawyer works on Friday.
5. Jack works two days before Karen, who works as the Chef.
6. Liam is not the Architect.

What is Helen's profession and on what day does she work?
questions.explanation:
1. George works Monday and is neither Engineer nor Lawyer.
2. Helen is the Doctor and works one day before Ian.
3. The Lawyer works Friday; hence, George is neither the Lawyer nor the Engineer; he must be the Teacher.
4. The Architect works before the Teacher, so George can't be the Architect, meaning the Teacher works on Monday and the Architect on Sunday. However, since the week starts on Monday, Architect works on Tuesday.
5. Helen is the Doctor, working Tuesday, and Ian Wednesday.
6. Jack works two days before Karen; Jack works Thursday as Chef.
7. The Lawyer works Friday, meaning Ian can't be Lawyer; he is Engineer working Thursday.
8. By elimination, Liam is Lawyer on Friday.
9. Karen works Saturday as Chef.
10. Thus, Helen works as a Doctor on Tuesday.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
There are seven people — Alice, Brian, Chloe, David, Ethan, Fiona, and Greg — who live in a seven-story building. Each of them has a different pet: Cat, Dog, Parrot, Rabbit, Fish, Hamster, and Turtle. Additionally, each prefers a different color: Red, Green, Blue, Yellow, Pink, Purple, and Orange. Determine who lives on which floor, their pet, and their preferred color based on the following clues:

1. Chloe lives on the 5th floor and prefers Red.
2. The Turtle owner lives on the 1st floor.
3. The person who prefers Green lives two floors above the Cat owner.
4. Ethan lives immediately below the person who prefers Pink and owns a Parrot.
5. Fiona owns a Dog and lives on an even-numbered floor but not the 4th.
6. The Fish owner prefers Yellow and lives three floors above Greg.
7. The Hamster owner lives between Alice and the person who prefers Blue.

Who owns the Rabbit and what floor do they live on?
questions.explanation:
1. Chloe lives on the 5th floor and prefers Red.
2. The Turtle owner on the 1st floor rules out Fiona for 2nd floor Dog owner.
3. Cat owner lives 2 floors below someone who prefers Green, so Cat owner must be on 3rd.
4. Ethan is below Pink Parrot owner, placing Ethan on 3rd or 4th.
5. Fiona on 2nd or 6th floors. As a Dog owner, she must be on 2nd.
6. Fish owner prefers Yellow and is 3 floors above Greg, so Fish owner must be on 7th, placing Greg on 4th.
7. Hamster owner between Alice and Blue preferrer, placing them on 6th.
8. By elimination, David owns the Rabbit and lives on the 4th floor.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
In a 9-to-5 job schedule, eight employees — Harry, Irene, Jack, Kelly, Leo, Mary, Nina, and Owen — each work a different hour from 9 AM to 4 PM. They all use different modes of transportation to work: Car, Bus, Bike, Train, Walk, Scooter, Subway, and Taxi. Their lunch preferences are different: Salad, Burger, Pasta, Sushi, Sandwich, Pizza, Tacos, and Noodles. Use the clues to determine each person's work hour, transportation, and lunch preference:

1. Harry works at 9 AM, travels by Scooter but doesn't like Sushi.
2. The person who works at 12 PM prefers Noodles and comes by Subway.
3. Jack prefers Salad and works before 11 AM.
4. The Taxi commuter works after the person who likes Burger.
5. The one who likes Tacos works at 10 AM.
6. Leo doesn't take the Bus or work at 1 PM.
7. Kelly works after 2 PM and prefers Pizza.
8. Owen travels by Bike and doesn't work before 11 AM.
9. Nina likes Pasta and works at 3 PM.
10. The person using Train works immediately after the Sandwich lover.

What is Mary's work hour, mode of transportation, and lunch preference?
questions.explanation:
1. Harry is 9 AM, Scooter, no Sushi.
2. 12 PM Noodles, Subway.
3. Jack's Salad, before 11 AM, likely 10 AM.
4. Tacos are at 10 AM.
5. Taxi post-Burger; hence Taxi not before 10 AM.
6. Leo doesn't Bus, not 1 PM, perhaps 4 PM.
7. Kelly post-2 PM Pizza, likely 4 PM.
8. Owen post-11 AM, Bike.
9. Nina 3 PM Pasta.
10. Train post-Sandwich, implying pre-lunch (before 12 PM).
11. Mary fits 1 PM, Car, Burger.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Ten colleagues — Alex, Ben, Clara, Dan, Eva, Frank, Grace, Helen, Ian, and Julia — each have a unique office number from 101 to 110. Each person has a different hobby: Painting, Chess, Gardening, Dancing, Music, Cooking, Reading, Traveling, Fishing, and Photography. They all have a favorite drink: Coffee, Tea, Juice, Water, Soda, Wine, Beer, Milk, Smoothie, and Cocktail. Determine each person's office, hobby, and favorite drink using these clues:

1. Ben's office is an even number and he likes Tea but not Chess.
2. The office next to Dan's belongs to the person who loves Fishing and prefers Juice.
3. The person who enjoys Traveling and has Soda works in office 109.
4. Grace loves Cooking and works in an office adjacent to the Music lover.
5. Clara is fond of Reading and has Milk, and her office number is even.
6. The Gardening enthusiast's favorite drink is Beer, and their office is directly next to Julia's.
7. Alex, who is in office 101, enjoys Photography.
8. Eva works two offices down from the Water drinker who loves Chess.
9. Frank likes Smoothies and works in office 110.
10. Helen, who likes Coffee, shares no office wall with the Traveling enthusiast.

Who works in office 107, and what is their hobby and favorite drink?
questions.explanation:
1. Ben, office 102, likes Tea.
2. Dan near Fishing, Juice.
3. Traveling, Soda in 109.
4. Grace loves Cooking, near Music.
5. Clara, Reading, Milk, even office 104.
6. Gardening, Beer, near Julia.
7. Alex, 101, Photography.
8. Eva two offices from Water, Chess.
9. Frank, Smoothies, 110.
10. Helen, Coffee, not near Traveling.
11. Dan in 107 fits Fishing, Juice.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Five friends, Anna, Ben, Clara, Dan, and Eva live in a building with five floors. Each person lives on a different floor (1 to 5) and has a favorite color (Red, Blue, Green, Yellow, and Purple). Ben lives above Clara. The person who likes Yellow lives on the lowest floor. Anna's floor is directly above the person who likes Purple. Eva lives on the second floor. Dan lives on the topmost floor. Who lives on the third floor?
questions.explanation: From the clues: 1. Dan lives on the 5th floor. 2. Eva lives on the 2nd floor. 3. The person who likes Yellow is on the 1st floor, so it can be either Anna or Clara. 4. Anna is above the person who likes Purple. 5. Ben is above Clara. Thus, Clara must be on the 1st floor (Yellow), Anna on 4th (Purple), Ben on 3rd, and Eva likes Green. Ben lives on the 3rd floor.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Seven people—Gina, Hank, Ivan, Jess, Kelly, Leo, and Mia—attend different workshops on different days of the week from Monday to Sunday. No two people attend on the same day. Gina attends the workshop on Wednesday. Hank attends after Gina but before Kelly. Mia attends on Friday. Jess attends before Ivan, who attends on Saturday. Leo attends immediately before Kelly. Who attends the workshop on Monday?
questions.explanation: 1. Gina is on Wednesday, Mia is on Friday. 2. Ivan on Saturday, Jess before Ivan. 3. Hank is after Gina and before Kelly, meaning Hank is on Thursday and Kelly is on Sunday. 4. Leo is before Kelly, making Leo on Saturday and Ivan on Sunday incorrect, so Leo is on Saturday and Ivan on Sunday. Therefore, Jess must be on Monday.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Six employees—Tom, Sam, Rita, Uma, Vince, and Zoe—have different professions: Doctor, Engineer, Teacher, Lawyer, Chef, and Artist. Each works in a different room labeled from 1 to 6. The Doctor works in room 5. Sam is not an Engineer. The Lawyer works in room 3 and is neither Tom nor Vince. The Artist works in room 2. Uma is not a Teacher. Zoe, who is an Engineer, works in room 4. Who is the Chef?
questions.explanation: 1. Zoe is an Engineer in room 4. 2. The Doctor in room 5 is neither Sam nor Uma since Uma isn't a Teacher. 3. The Lawyer in room 3 is not Tom or Vince, so it must be Sam. 4. Artist in room 2, not Tom or Vince, must be Uma. 5. Rita must be the Chef (since the remaining profession is Chef), and she works in room 1. Therefore, Rita is the Chef.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Eight friends—Alex, Brian, Chris, Diana, Elise, Frank, George, and Hannah—attend different clubs: Chess, Robotics, Art, Drama, Music, Debate, Science, and Photography. Each one drives a different colored car: Red, Blue, Green, Yellow, Black, White, Purple, and Orange. Alex drives the Red car and doesn't attend Chess or Robotics. The person who drives the Blue car attends Science club. Chris, who doesn't drive a Yellow car, is in the Photography club. Hannah drives the White car. Diana attends Robotics and drives a Black car. Brian is in Drama. Elise drives a Green car and attends Art. Frank is in Debate. Who drives the Purple car?
questions.explanation: 1. Alex drives Red and not in Chess or Robotics. 2. Blue car is in Science, so it cannot be Alex. 3. Chris in Photography, can't have Yellow, so Purple or Orange. 4. Hannah is White and not Alex or Chris. 5. Diana is Black and in Robotics. 6. Elise in Art is Green. 7. Brian in Drama can't be Blue or Yellow. 8. Frank in Debate and can't be Blue or Yellow, so Purple. 9. Therefore, Frank drives the Purple car.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Nine people are seated around a circular table. Each person is a different age (between 21 and 29) and has a distinct favorite number between 1 and 9. Jessica, who is 24, sits between the person whose favorite number is 2 and the person who is 26 years old. The person who is 28 years old sits opposite the one whose favorite number is 6. Peter is 23 and sits next to the person whose favorite number is 4. The person who is 25 years old is two places left of the one whose favorite number is 7. The youngest person sits opposite the one whose favorite number is 9. Who is the oldest person seated at the table?

options.C: The one whose favorite number is 5
options.D: The one whose favorite number is 3
options.E: The one whose favorite number is 9

questions.explanation: 1. Identify the seating order step-by-step based on favorite numbers and age constraints. 2. Connect the given ages with favorite numbers logically around the table. 3. The oldest, 29, must correspond to the unallocated seat after fulfilling all adjacent conditions. 4. Cross-reference the given age constraints with seating positions to find the correct answer, which is linked to the favorite number 5.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Five friends, Alex, Bob, Charlie, David, and Eve, live on different floors of a five-story building (numbered 1 to 5 from the bottom to the top). Each friend likes a different color (Red, Blue, Green, Yellow, and Pink). The following conditions are given: 1. Alex lives on the fourth floor. 2. The person who likes Blue lives on an even-numbered floor. 3. Bob likes Green and lives one floor above Charlie. 4. David lives on the first floor and does not like Yellow. 5. Eve does not live on the top floor. Who lives on the fifth floor and which color do they like?
questions.explanation: 1. Alex lives on the fourth floor. 2. Bob must live on the fifth floor, because he lives above Charlie and only fifth floor is above any other floor, thus Charlie is on the fourth floor. 3. Bob likes Green. 4. David lives on the first floor and cannot like Yellow, leaving him with Red. 5. Therefore, the person who likes Blue can only be Eve and since she can't live on the top floor, Eve lives on the second floor. 6. Thus, the person on the third floor must like Yellow. 7. Therefore, Bob is on the fifth floor and must like Red.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Seven students, Andy, Brian, Cindy, Donna, Ethan, Fiona, and George, participated in a sports event and each won a different medal (Gold, Silver, Bronze, Copper, Iron, Platinum, and Tin). Each student also likes a different fruit (Apple, Banana, Cherry, Dates, Fig, Grapes, and Kiwi). The following conditions are known: 1. Andy won the Gold medal and does not like Dates. 2. The student who likes Banana won the Silver medal. 3. Cindy likes Cherry but did not win the Bronze medal. 4. Ethan won the Iron medal. 5. Fiona likes Grapes and won the Platinum medal. 6. The student who won the Bronze medal likes Fig. 7. Donna did not win the Tin medal but likes Dates. 8. George likes Apple. Who won the Copper medal and what is their favorite fruit?
questions.explanation: 1. Andy won Gold and does not like Dates, so Andy's fruit is not Dates. 2. Banana goes with Silver, but it is not specified who won Silver yet. 3. Cindy likes Cherry, and since Cindy did not win Bronze, Cindy's medal could be Copper. 4. Ethan won Iron, fixing his position. 5. Fiona won Platinum and likes Grapes. 6. Fig goes with Bronze. 7. Donna likes Dates but did not win Tin, so her medal must be one of the other remaining options (Copper or Bronze). 8. George likes Apple but not paired yet with a medal, so Copper matches Cindy who likes Cherry.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Six friends are traveling to different countries: USA, Canada, UK, Australia, Germany, and Japan. Their professions are different: Doctor, Engineer, Teacher, Lawyer, Chef, and Artist. They are traveling in different months: January, February, March, April, May, and June. The clues are: 1. The Doctor is traveling in March to UK. 2. The Engineer is traveling in April but not to Germany. 3. The Teacher travels to USA but not in January or June. 4. The person traveling to Japan is an Artist and goes in May. 5. The Chef travels to Australia but not in February. 6. The Lawyer is traveling in June. 7. The person traveling to Canada goes in February. Who is the Lawyer and where are they traveling?
questions.explanation: 1. The Doctor is fixed in March to UK. 2. The Engineer is in April but not Germany, so possibilities are USA or Canada. 3. Teacher is USA not January or June, so either March or May. March is already occupied by Doctor, so May or February. But February is for Canada, so March is for Teacher USA. 4. The Artist is in May in Japan. 5. Chef is in Australia, not February, which leaves June or April. April is for Engineer, so Chef must be June. 6. Thus, Lawyer is also in June, and they go to Germany as all other options are accounted for.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Nine colleagues, Harry, Ian, Jack, Kate, Linda, Mike, Nancy, Oscar, and Paula, live in a nine-floor building with one person per floor. Each has a different hobby (Gardening, Painting, Cycling, Cooking, Reading, Writing, Dancing, Hiking, and Photography) and a different favorite animal (Dog, Cat, Bird, Fish, Rabbit, Hamster, Turtle, Horse, and Snake). The following clues are given: 1. Harry lives two floors above the person who likes Painting. 2. The person who likes Photography lives on the top floor. 3. Ian's favorite animal is a Rabbit and he lives below the fifth floor. 4. The person who enjoys Cooking lives immediately above Mike, whose favorite animal is a Cat. 5. The person who likes Gardening has a Hamster and lives on the third floor. 6. Jack lives between the person who likes Cycling and the person who likes Hiking. 7. Kate enjoys Dancing and her favorite animal is a Dog. 8. Linda lives on the floor just above the person who likes Reading. 9. Nancy's favorite animal is a Turtle and she lives three floors below the Photography enthusiast. 10. Oscar, who lives on an even-numbered floor, likes Writing. 11. Paula's favorite animal is a Fish, and she does not live on the top floor. Who lives on the second floor and what are their hobby and favorite animal?
questions.explanation: 1. Harry's and Painting's positions guide to Harry being around 6 or 7 if Painting is at 4 or 5, respectively. 2. Photography is on the 9th floor. 3. Ian and Rabbit must be below 5, so 1-4 range, but not 3 which is Gardening. 4. Cooking is above Mike, 3 becomes Gardening, so Mike is 2 or 1, but due to Ian, 2. 5. 6-7 with Harry, Painting comes below, probably 5, and thus Jack needs between Cycling and Hiking. 6. Kate's Dog means she could be in early floors due to the 2 gap. 7. Linda is above Reading. 8. Nancy below Photography by 3 and enjoys Turtle. 9. Oscar on even with Writing, making it 4/6/8. 10. Paula with Fish not on 9. Hence, Mike is on 2 with Cycling and Cat due to combinations with constraints.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Ten friends, Anna, Barry, Carla, David, Emma, Frank, Gina, Helen, Ivy, and Jack, each own a different type of vehicle (Sedan, Coupe, Hatchback, SUV, Truck, Convertible, Minivan, Motorcycle, Bicycle, and Van) and live on a different street named after a city (New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, Houston, Phoenix, Philadelphia, San Antonio, San Diego, Dallas, and San Jose). Each person's favorite sport is different: Basketball, Football, Tennis, Cricket, Baseball, Swimming, Golf, Hockey, Soccer, and Rugby. Conditions: 1. Anna lives on New York street and owns a Sedan. 2. The owner of the Truck lives on Chicago street and does not like Cricket. 3. The person who likes Soccer lives on Houston street and owns a Minivan. 4. Emma, who likes Basketball, lives in Philadelphia but does not own a Motorcycle. 5. Gina lives on San Diego street and owns a Coupe. 6. The person who owns the Hatchback likes Golf and lives on Los Angeles street. 7. The resident of San Jose street likes Tennis. 8. Barry lives on San Antonio street and does not own a Convertible. 9. Frank, who likes Baseball, lives on Dallas street but not in a Van. 10. Jack enjoys Hockey and lives in Phoenix. Who lives on San Jose street, what vehicle do they own, and what is their favorite sport?
questions.explanation: 1. Anna on New York with Sedan. 2. Truck on Chicago, not Cricket. 3. Soccer and Minivan on Houston. 4. Emma Basketball at Philadelphia, Motorcycle is out. 5. Gina on San Diego with Coupe. 6. Hatchback, Golf on Los Angeles. 7. Tennis on San Jose, leaving open vehicle options. 8. Barry on San Antonio not Convertible. 9. Frank at Dallas not Van, must be Baseball. 10. Jack, Hockey at Phoenix, cross-check options against remaining streets and sports, vehicles align to Ivy for Tennis at San Jose with SUV.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Five employees - Alex, Brooke, Casey, Dylan, and Evan - have presentations scheduled on five consecutive days from Monday to Friday. The following conditions must be satisfied: 
1. Alex's presentation is on Monday.
2. Casey's presentation is two days after Brooke's.
3. Dylan's presentation is the day before Evan's.
4. Evan's presentation is not on Friday.
Who gives their presentation on Tuesday?
questions.explanation: Alex is on Monday, and Dylan is a day before Evan. Evan is not on Friday, so Evan is on Thursday and Dylan on Wednesday. Casey is two days after Brooke, hence Brooke must be on Tuesday and Casey on Thursday. Thus, Brooke gives her presentation on Tuesday.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Seven friends - Gary, Helen, Irene, James, Kevin, Lisa, and Mona - visit a library on different days of the same week, starting from Monday to Sunday. Each of them also reads a unique book: A, B, C, D, E, F, and G. Consider the following conditions:
1. Gary visits before Mona but after Lisa.
2. Kevin visits on Wednesday.
3. The person who reads book D visits on Friday.
4. Irene visits the day before the person who reads book C.
5. Helen visits after the person who reads book F.
6. James reads book B.
7. The person who visits on Sunday reads book G.
Who reads book A?
questions.explanation: Kevin visits on Wednesday. Book D is read on Friday, hence Helen must visit before Friday. Lisa visits on Monday, followed by Gary on Tuesday. Irene visits on Thursday and reads book A, which is before the book C reader on Friday. Mona visits on Saturday, Helen on Sunday reading book G.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Eight people - Alan, Beth, Carl, Dana, Ed, Finn, Gina, and Hanna - attend workshops across eight distinct time slots, Monday to Sunday, with an extra slot on Monday afternoon. The following conditions apply:
1. Alan attends after Dana but before Beth.
2. Carl and Finn attend on the same day, Finn's workshop is in the afternoon.
3. Ed's session is not on Tuesday.
4. Gina attends immediately before Hanna.
5. The Monday afternoon slot is taken by someone whose name starts with a vowel.
6. Dana attends on Friday.
7. Hanna attends the day before Carl and Finn.
Which day does Beth attend?
questions.explanation: Dana is on Friday. Alan after Dana, but before Beth, suggests Beth on Saturday. Carl and Finn on the same day with Finn in the afternoon, likely Monday if not Tuesday (due to Ed), and Gina-Hanna sequence means Hanna on Monday, making Carl and Finn on Tuesday. Ed slots in on Sunday.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
In a two-week schedule, 10 projects labeled A through J are planned, with each project starting on a distinct day. Each project lasts exactly one day. The two weeks start on a Monday. The following rules must be followed:
1. Project A starts on the first Monday.
2. Project B starts after Project D, but not on the same week as Project A.
3. Project E starts on the day after Project F.
4. Project G starts two days before Project H, which starts two days before Project I.
5. Project J starts after Project C but on a Tuesday.
Which day does Project G start?
questions.explanation: Project A starts on Monday of Week 1. Project B is after D in Week 2. Project E is after F on consecutive days, so they fit in Week 1. Project G is two days before H, which is two days before I, placing G on Monday Week 2. Project J is on the Tuesday after C, fitting with the second week constraint.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Nine conferences are planned for a technology summit, taking place over three months: April, May, and June. Each month sees conferences held on the 5th, 15th, and 25th. The following conditions must be respected:
1. The AI conference is on the same date as the Networking conference but in the following month.
2. The Cybersecurity conference is on April 5th.
3. The Blockchain conference is held two days before the Data Science conference in any given month.
4. The IoT conference is after the Cloud Computing conference, but in the same month.
5. The VR conference and the Robotics conference are held in consecutive months, but not the same month as AI.
6. The AI conference is not in June.
On which date is the Data Science conference held?
questions.explanation: The AI conference is in May on the 15th, followed by Networking in June on the 15th. Cybersecurity on April 5th, placing Blockchain and Data Science in April on 23rd and 25th respectively. IoT and Cloud Computing can fit in May 5th and 25th or June 5th, dependent on earlier placements. VR/Robotics can be adjusted accordingly, fitting the only available slot for the latter conferences.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Five friends (Amy, Ben, Cara, Dan, and Eva) decided to meet once during the weekdays (Monday to Friday). Each one meets on a different day. The conditions are as follows: 1) Ben meets before Dan. 2) Cara meets two days after Amy. 3) Eva meets on Wednesday. On which day does Dan meet?
questions.explanation: Eva meets on Wednesday. Amy must meet on Monday for Cara to meet two days later on Wednesday. Ben meets before Dan, so Ben meets on Tuesday, allowing Dan to meet on Friday.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Seven tasks (T1, T2, T3, T4, T5, T6, T7) are to be completed over a week (Monday to Sunday). The following conditions must be met: 1) T1 must be completed before T5. 2) T3 must be completed on Monday or Tuesday. 3) T6 is completed the day after T3. 4) T4 is completed on a weekend day. 5) T2 must be completed on Wednesday. Which task is completed on Sunday?
questions.explanation: T3 can only be completed on Monday, making T6 on Tuesday, and T2 on Wednesday. T1 before T5 could be Thursday or Friday. T4 is on a weekend, either Saturday or Sunday, so T7 is completed on Sunday.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Eight employees (P, Q, R, S, T, U, V, W) must each conduct a training session over eight consecutive days, starting from 1st October to 8th October. The conditions are: 1) P's session is 3 days after Q's. 2) R conducts his session immediately after S. 3) T and U conduct their sessions on consecutive days, with T ahead of U. 4) V's session is on 5th October. 5) W's session is 2 days after P's. On which day does S conduct his session?
questions.explanation: V is on 5th October. If P is on 3rd, then Q is on 1st, allowing W to be on 5th, but that overlaps with V. Thus, Q is on 3rd, P on 6th, W on 8th, R is on 3rd. S must be on 2nd to allow R immediately after, leaving T on 1st and U on 2nd.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Ten workshops (W1, W2, W3, ..., W10) are scheduled across five consecutive days in a month (1st to 5th). Each day hosts two workshops: one in the morning, one in the afternoon. Conditions: 1) W1 is on the afternoon of the first day. 2) W5 is two days after W1. 3) W6 and W7 are on the same day. 4) W3 is immediately after W2. 5) W8 is in the afternoon of the day before W5. 6) W9 is not on the first or second day. Which workshop is scheduled on the morning of the third day?
questions.explanation: W1 is on the afternoon of the 1st, and W5 is on the 3rd day in the afternoon. W8 is the afternoon of the 2nd. W2 then W3 are on the morning of the 3rd, making W3 the answer. W6 and W7 share a day, only possible on the 4th. W9 is on the 5th.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Nine different events are scheduled over the span of three months: January, February, and March. Each month hosts exactly three events. Conditions are: 1) Event A is scheduled before Event B. 2) Event C and Event D are in different months. 3) Event E is in February, but not the last event. 4) Event F is scheduled immediately after Event G, and both are in March. 5) Event H is not in January. 6) The first event of March is Event I. In which month is Event B scheduled?

options.D: Could be either February or March

questions.explanation: Given Event F and G must be in March, and F follows G, I is the first. This sets A in January for B to follow. Event E being in February before last means C or D joins it in a non-January position. A must be the first month, ensuring B follows in January.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: There are five meetings scheduled across a week from Monday to Friday. The meetings are with different clients: Alpha, Beta, Gamma, Delta, and Epsilon. The schedule must follow these constraints: 1) The meeting with Alpha is on Monday. 2) There is one meeting between Beta and Gamma. 3) Delta's meeting is the day after Gamma's. 4) Epsilon's meeting is not on Wednesday. On which day is the meeting with Epsilon?
questions.explanation: From the conditions: 1) Alpha is on Monday. 2) The meeting with Beta is either on Tuesday or Thursday since there must be a meeting in between Beta and Gamma. 3) Delta follows Gamma, so they must be on consecutive days. 4) Epsilon cannot be on Wednesday, so by elimination, Epsilon's meeting is on Thursday. The final arrangement is: Monday - Alpha, Tuesday - Gamma, Wednesday - Delta, Thursday - Epsilon, Friday - Beta.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Eight employees—Adam, Brian, Charlie, David, Ethan, Frank, George, and Harry—need to present their projects on eight different days in March from 1st to 8th. The conditions are: 1) Adam presents on the 1st. 2) Ethan presents two days after Charlie. 3) David's presentation is between Frank and George's presentations. 4) Brian presents immediately before Harry. 5) Frank presents on an odd-numbered day. Who presents on the 5th?
questions.explanation: 1) Adam is on the 1st. 2) Charlie must present on the 3rd for Ethan to be on the 5th. 3) Frank must be on the 5th due to being on an odd day, so Ethan must be on the 6th. 4) Brian and Harry must be consecutive, so they can only be on the 2nd and 3rd, which places Harry on the 3rd and Brian on the 2nd. 5) That places David on the 4th, between Frank and George. Thus, George must be on the 6th. Therefore, Frank presents on the 5th.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A conference is held over six months from January to June with six keynote speakers: A, B, C, D, E, and F. The following conditions apply: 1) A speaks in March. 2) B speaks one month before C. 3) D speaks two months after B. 4) E speaks in May. 5) F does not speak in June. Determine the month when F gives his speech.
questions.explanation: 1) A is set for March. 2) B and C are consecutive, with B before C. The only possibility is B in February and C in March (as A is already in March, C must be April). 3) D is two months after B, so D is in April. 4) E is in May. F cannot be in June, so F must be in April. Therefore, F speaks in April.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Five friends—P, Q, R, S, and T—participate in a marathon, each finishing the race on different days of a week from Monday to Friday. The conditions are: 1) P finishes the race two days before Q. 2) R does not finish on the first or last day. 3) S finishes on an odd-numbered day of the week. 4) T finishes after P. 5) There is exactly one day between the finish days of Q and S. Who finishes the race on Wednesday?
questions.explanation: 1) P must finish on Monday or Tuesday, but due to T finishing after, P is on Monday. 2) Q is on Wednesday. 3) R can't be Monday or Friday, so R must be on Wednesday. 4) S must finish on an odd day (Monday, Wednesday, or Friday), but since R is on Wednesday and Q can't be Friday, S is on Monday. 5) T must be on Thursday. The arrangement is: Monday - P, Tuesday - S, Wednesday - R, Thursday - Q, Friday - T.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Ten tasks labeled A to J need to be completed over five weeks, with each week having two tasks. The conditions are: 1) Task A is completed in the first week. 2) Task B is completed in the last week. 3) There is a one-week gap between tasks C and D. 4) Task E is completed before tasks F and G but after task H. 5) Task J is completed in the same week as task F. In which week is task C completed?
questions.explanation: 1) A is in week 1. 2) B is in week 5. 3) C and D must be in weeks 3 and 5 (with a one-week gap), so C is in week 3. 4) E is before F and G but after H, meaning E is in week 2. 5) J is in the same week as F, so F and J are in week 4. Thus, task C is completed in week 3.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: There are five friends: John, Mike, Sara, Lily, and Alex. Each of them is free on a different day from Monday to Friday. John is free two days before Sara. Mike is free on the day before John. Lily is free two days after Mike. Who is free on Thursday?
questions.explanation: Mike is free on Monday, John is free on Tuesday, Sara is free on Thursday, and Lily is free on Thursday. Therefore, Lily is free on Thursday.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Eight tasks, A through H, need to be completed over the next four days. Two tasks are completed each day. Task A is done before task B but on the same day as task D. Task C is done two days after task E, which is done on the first day. Task G and H are done on consecutive days. If task F is done on the last day, which tasks are done on the third day?
questions.explanation: Task E is on the first day, so task C is on the third day. Since task F is on the last day, task G must be on the third day with task C. Hence, tasks C and G are done on the third day.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Seven seminars on different subjects (Math, Science, English, History, Geography, Art, and Music) are scheduled across seven months: January through July. The Math seminar is before the Science seminar. The English seminar is two months after the Art seminar. The History seminar is scheduled in a month before the Geography seminar. The Music seminar is neither the first nor the last. Which month is the English seminar?
questions.explanation: Art is in March, so English is in May. Math and Science must be in January and February. History is before Geography, placing Geography in June, leaving July for History and May for English.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Ten employees (P, Q, R, S, T, U, V, W, X, Y) are given tasks from Monday to Sunday, with some days having more than one task but no task on the same day for more than two employees. P's task is before Q's. R's task is neither on Tuesday nor Wednesday. X's task is three days after W's. V is not working on Sunday. T and U work on consecutive days. If Y's task is on Saturday, on which day is U's task?
questions.explanation: Following the conditions, if Y is on Saturday, and V can't be on Sunday, and T and U work consecutively, U has to be on Wednesday with T on Tuesday to fit the constraints.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: In a weekly programming contest schedule from Monday to Sunday, each contest (Java, Python, Ruby, C++, Swift, JavaScript, PHP) is held once. Java is not on a weekend. The C++ contest is two days before the Ruby contest. Python contest is after the Swift contest. JavaScript contest is not on Monday or Saturday, and PHP contest is not on Tuesday or Friday. On which day is the Ruby contest held?
questions.explanation: Considering all conditions, C++ on Wednesday places Ruby on Friday. Python can be on Sunday after Swift on Thursday, and with constraints for JavaScript and PHP, all slots fit the sequence.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Five friends, Alex, Ben, Charlie, David, and Ethan, have scheduled meetings on five consecutive days from Monday to Friday. Each friend has one meeting on a different day. Based on the following clues, determine which friend has a meeting on which day: 
1. Alex's meeting is before Ben's. 
2. Charlie has his meeting two days after Alex. 
3. David has his meeting the day before Ethan. 
4. Ben has his meeting on Wednesday.
questions.explanation: Given Ben is on Wednesday, Alex must be before Wednesday and Charlie two days after Alex. The only possibility that fits all conditions is: Alex-Monday, Ben-Wednesday, Charlie-Thursday, David-Tuesday, Ethan-Friday.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Seven employees, G, H, I, J, K, L, and M, are assigned tasks from Monday to Sunday. Each employee has one task per day. The following conditions must be met: 
1. G's task is earlier in the week than L's. 
2. J's task is on Tuesday. 
3. H has his task the day after K. 
4. M's task is not on a weekend. 
5. L's task is on Friday.

options.A: G-Monday, H-Wednesday, I-Saturday, J-Tuesday, K-Thursday, L-Friday, M-Sunday
options.B: G-Tuesday, H-Thursday, I-Saturday, J-Monday, K-Wednesday, L-Friday, M-Sunday
options.C: G-Wednesday, H-Tuesday, I-Sunday, J-Monday, K-Thursday, L-Friday, M-Saturday
options.D: G-Monday, H-Thursday, I-Sunday, J-Tuesday, K-Wednesday, L-Friday, M-Saturday
options.E: G-Monday, H-Tuesday, I-Thursday, J-Wednesday, K-Friday, L-Saturday, M-Sunday

questions.explanation: Given J is on Tuesday and L is on Friday, H must follow K, leaving K on Wednesday. G precedes L, so G is on Monday. M is not on the weekend, so M is on Saturday, leaving I for Sunday.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Eight lectures on different subjects are scheduled from Monday to Thursday in a university, two lectures per day. The subjects are: Physics, Chemistry, Biology, Mathematics, History, Geography, Literature, and Economics. Consider the following: 
1. Physics and Chemistry are scheduled on the same day. 
2. History is scheduled before Literature. 
3. Mathematics is not scheduled on Wednesday. 
4. Economics is scheduled on the same day as Biology. 
5. Geography is scheduled on Wednesday. 
6. No subject is scheduled on consecutive periods on the same day.

options.A: Monday: Physics, Chemistry; Tuesday: Biology, Economics; Wednesday: Geography, Mathematics; Thursday: History, Literature
options.B: Monday: History, Literature; Tuesday: Physics, Chemistry; Wednesday: Biology, Economics; Thursday: Geography, Mathematics
options.C: Monday: Geography, Mathematics; Tuesday: Physics, Chemistry; Wednesday: History, Literature; Thursday: Biology, Economics
options.D: Monday: Mathematics, Economics; Tuesday: Physics, Chemistry; Wednesday: Geography, Biology; Thursday: History, Literature
options.E: Monday: History, Geography; Tuesday: Chemistry, Physics; Wednesday: Economics, Biology; Thursday: Literature, Mathematics

questions.explanation: Physics and Chemistry must be paired. Geography is on Wednesday. Mathematics can't be on Wednesday, leaving History and Literature for Thursday. Economics and Biology pair on Tuesday. Thus, the distribution is: Monday - Physics, Chemistry; Tuesday - Biology, Economics; Wednesday - Geography, Mathematics; Thursday - History, Literature.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Ten students, P, Q, R, S, T, U, V, W, X, and Y, are participating in a quiz contest held on different days in two weeks (Monday to Friday). Each student participates on one unique day, and no quiz is held on weekends. The conditions are as follows: 
1. P participates earlier than R. 
2. V is on Monday of the second week. 
3. S is scheduled two days after T. 
4. U and W have consecutive day slots. 
5. Y's quiz is not on a Friday. 
6. Q is scheduled before both P and Y. 
7. X is scheduled on Thursday of the first week.

options.A: Week 1: P-Monday, Q-Tuesday, R-Wednesday, X-Thursday, T-Friday; Week 2: U-Monday, V-Tuesday, W-Wednesday, S-Thursday, Y-Friday
options.B: Week 1: V-Monday, Q-Tuesday, R-Wednesday, S-Thursday, Y-Friday; Week 2: P-Monday, U-Tuesday, W-Wednesday, T-Thursday, X-Friday
options.C: Week 1: X-Monday, Q-Tuesday, P-Wednesday, R-Thursday, T-Friday; Week 2: V-Monday, S-Tuesday, U-Wednesday, W-Thursday, Y-Friday
options.D: Week 1: Q-Monday, R-Tuesday, P-Wednesday, X-Thursday, T-Friday; Week 2: V-Monday, U-Tuesday, W-Wednesday, S-Thursday, Y-Friday
options.E: Week 1: Q-Monday, X-Tuesday, R-Wednesday, Y-Thursday, T-Friday; Week 2: V-Monday, U-Tuesday, W-Wednesday, S-Thursday, P-Friday

questions.explanation: Given X on Thursday in the first week, V on second Monday, and S two days after T, arranging U and W consecutively leads to: Week 1: Q-Monday, R-Tuesday, P-Wednesday, X-Thursday, T-Friday; Week 2: V-Monday, U-Tuesday, W-Wednesday, S-Thursday, Y-Friday.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Nine seminars on subjects A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, and I are scheduled in a month having 30 days. Each seminar is on a different day, and some specific conditions need to be satisfied: 
1. Seminar A is held before seminar D. 
2. Seminars B and C are on consecutive days. 
3. Seminar F is held three days after seminar G. 
4. Seminar E is held on a weekend. 
5. Seminars H and I are not on consecutive days. 
6. Seminar I is held on a day before seminar A. 
7. Seminar G is scheduled in the first week.

options.A: G-1st, F-4th, B-8th, C-9th, I-10th, A-12th, D-15th, E-22nd, H-27th
options.B: G-2nd, F-5th, B-10th, C-11th, I-14th, A-16th, D-20th, E-23rd, H-28th
options.C: G-4th, F-7th, B-12th, C-13th, I-15th, A-17th, D-21st, E-24th, H-29th
options.D: G-3rd, F-6th, B-9th, C-10th, I-11th, A-13th, D-18th, E-25th, H-30th
options.E: G-5th, F-8th, B-11th, C-12th, I-15th, A-17th, D-22nd, E-26th, H-30th

questions.explanation: G is on the 3rd, F follows on the 6th. B and C need consecutive slots, positioning them on 9th and 10th respectively. I precedes A, so on 11th and 13th, allowing A on 13th. Seminar D follows, placed on the 18th. E lands on a weekend, such as 25th, leaving H for the 30th.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Five friends - Alice, Bob, Charlie, Dave, and Eve - have different activities scheduled on different days of the week, from Monday to Friday. The activities are as follows: Gym, Cooking class, Yoga, Guitar lesson, and Dance class. Each activity is on a different day. The following conditions apply:
1. Alice's activity is on Wednesday.
2. Bob's activity is on the day before Gym.
3. Charlie attends Cooking class, which is on Thursday.
4. Dave's activity is on Friday.
5. Eve's activity is not on Monday.
Which day is Gym scheduled?
questions.explanation:
Based on the conditions:
1. Alice's activity is on Wednesday.
2. Charlie's Cooking class is on Thursday.
3. Dave's activity is on Friday.
4. Eve's activity cannot be on Monday (or she would be doing Bob's activity, which is before Gym). Hence, Eve is on Wednesday, doing Yoga.
5. Bob's activity is on Tuesday, which is before Gym.
Thus, Gym is scheduled for Tuesday. Therefore, the correct answer is B: Tuesday.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Seven employees - Mark, Nina, Oliver, Paula, Quentin, Rachel, and Steve - have meetings scheduled on different days of a week, from Monday to Sunday. The meeting times are unique and scheduled either in the morning or afternoon. The following clues can be used:
1. Mark's meeting is on Tuesday morning.
2. Nina's meeting is scheduled the day after Steve's.
3. Oliver's meeting is neither on the weekend nor in the afternoon.
4. Paula's meeting is on Saturday afternoon.
5. Quentin has a meeting on Friday, but not in the morning.
6. Rachel's meeting is on a day after a weekend.
What day is Steve's meeting scheduled on?
questions.explanation:
1. Mark has a meeting on Tuesday morning.
2. Oliver's meeting must be on a weekday morning, so it's on Wednesday morning since Tuesday morning is taken by Mark.
3. Paula's meeting is on Saturday afternoon.
4. Quentin's meeting is on Friday afternoon.
5. Nina must be the day after Steve, and Rachel's meeting is after a weekend, likely Monday since Paula has Saturday.
6. Therefore, Steve's meeting is on Monday.
Thus, Steve's meeting is on Monday, making the answer A.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Eight students - Andy, Beth, Carol, David, Emma, Fred, Gina, and Henry - are scheduled for different sports practices on different days, from Monday to Thursday, in both morning and afternoon slots. The activities are Football, Basketball, Tennis, and Swimming. Each sport has one morning and one afternoon slot. Consider the following clues:
1. Andy has his practice on Tuesday afternoon.
2. Beth is scheduled for Football on Monday.
3. Carol's practice is the morning after Emma's practice.
4. David has Tennis practice in the morning.
5. Fred's practice is on the same day as Gina's but in the afternoon.
6. Henry has his practice on Wednesday morning.
7. Swimming is scheduled the day before Gina's practice.
Which day is Gina's practice scheduled on?
questions.explanation:
1. Henry's Wednesday morning practice means Emma's practice must be on Tuesday morning, as Carol follows Emma in the morning.
2. Swimming, being a day before Gina's practice, can only be on Tuesday if Gina is Wednesday.
3. Andy's Tuesday afternoon practice aligns with Swimming (since it must be Andy).
4. Fred and Gina share a day, and Gina's practice must be on Wednesday.
Thus, Gina's practice is scheduled on Wednesday, making the answer C.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Nine different seminars - Biology, Chemistry, Physics, Mathematics, Statistics, Economics, History, Geography, and English - are scheduled across three different weeks (Monday to Friday only). Each seminar is scheduled exactly once per week. The following conditions apply:
1. The Biology seminar is always on Monday.
2. Chemistry is scheduled on the day before Statistics.
3. History is scheduled the same day as Economics but in different weeks.
4. Physics is on Wednesday in the first week.
5. Mathematics never coincides with Geography on the same week.
6. English follows Geography immediately.
7. The last seminar of any week is either Economics or Statistics.
Determine the day and week of the Geography seminar in the first week.
questions.explanation:
1. Biology on Monday fixes Monday for the first week.
2. Physics is Wednesday in the first week.
3. Geography cannot be on Wednesday due to Physics. If Geography is on Tuesday in the first week, English follows on Wednesday, but Physics is there.
4. Thus, Geography must be Thursday, followed by English on Friday.
5. Mathematics can align with Geography as Chemistry must be Tuesday (the day before Statistics).
Therefore, Geography is scheduled for Thursday in the first week, making the answer C.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Ten university lectures, each on different topics, are scheduled on different days over two consecutive weeks (Monday to Friday). The topics are Psychology, Sociology, Anthropology, Philosophy, Linguistics, Mathematics, Computer Science, Physics, Chemistry, and Biology. Each week has five lectures. The constraints are:
1. The Psychology lecture is always the first lecture of each week.
2. Sociology and Anthropology lectures are scheduled in the same week but not consecutively.
3. Mathematics is scheduled immediately before Chemistry.
4. Computer Science is never in the same week as Philosophy.
5. Linguistics is in the second week, two days after Computer Science.
6. Physics is the last lecture of the first week.
7. Biology is scheduled in the first week but not on the first or last day.
Determine the schedule for the Chemistry lecture.
questions.explanation:
1. Psychology is Monday for both weeks.
2. Physics is Friday of the first week.
3. Mathematics must be right before Chemistry. So, they should be aligned such that Chemistry can be slotted somewhere between Tuesday and Thursday.
4. By constraint, Chemistry can go on Thursday of Week 1, with Mathematics on Wednesday.
Thus, Chemistry is scheduled for Thursday of the first week, making the answer C.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Four friends, A, B, C, and D, are sitting at a square table, one on each side, facing the center. A sits on the north side, B sits opposite A. D sits to the left of C. Who sits on the east side?
questions.explanation: A sits on the north side, so B must sit on the south side. D sits to the left of C, so C must be on the west side, and D on the east side. Hence, D sits on the east side.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Eight people, P, Q, R, S, T, U, V, and W, are sitting around a square table in such a way that two sit on each side. Some are facing the center, and others are facing outside. U sits second to the right of Q, who faces the center. P is not an immediate neighbor of U or Q. V sits third to the left of P. R sits second to the right of T, who faces the center. S sits opposite to V, who faces outside. Who sits to the immediate right of R?
questions.explanation: U is second to the right of Q, who faces the center. Given the constraints, W sits to the immediate right of R, based on deductions from the seating arrangement.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Six friends, A, B, C, D, E, and F, are sitting around a triangular table with two people on each side. The ones sitting at the corners are facing outside while those sitting in the middle of the sides are facing the center. A sits at a corner and F sits in the middle of a side. B is not an immediate neighbor of F and sits opposite D. E sits to the immediate right of C. Who sits to the immediate left of D?
questions.explanation: Given the conditions, A sits at one corner, F in the middle, and E sits immediately to the right of C. D sits opposite B. Thus, E is to the immediate left of D.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Twelve people are sitting around a hexagonal table with two on each side. The table has six corners, and the people at the corners are facing the center, while others face outside. A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I, J, K, and L are sitting such that A sits second to the right of D. G sits third to the left of J, who is not an immediate neighbor of D. C sits opposite to F and is third to the right of K. E sits at one of the corners, and B is not an immediate neighbor of H. Who is sitting opposite to L?
questions.explanation: Placing the given conditions, you determine positions step-by-step: L sits at a corner, with J sitting opposite due to G's placement and subsequent calculations.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Fifteen people are divided into three groups of five, each group sitting at a separate rectangular table. The first table has people sitting with all facing the center, the second has all facing outside, and the third has mixed directions. At the first table, M sits opposite to N. At the second table, O is second to the right of P. At the third table, Q sits diagonally opposite to R, who sits on a corner. S is an immediate neighbor of T at the first table and sits directly opposite to U at the second table. Who is sitting diagonally opposite to V at the third table?
questions.explanation: After arranging the three tables and considering each position, it is deduced that X is diagonally opposite to V at the third table based on all given clues and deductions.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Four friends, A, B, C, and D, are sitting at a square table, one on each side. They are all facing the center. A is sitting to the west of B. C is sitting to the south of D. Who is sitting on the north side?
questions.explanation: If A is sitting to the west of B, B must be on the east side. Given C is south of D, D must be on the north side, and C is on the south side. Therefore, B is on the east, C on the south, D on the north, and A on the west.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Eight people (P, Q, R, S, T, U, V, W) are sitting around a square table with two people on each side. All are facing outward. P is sitting second to the left of Q. R and T are sitting opposite to each other. S is on the immediate right of U, who is not next to T. Who is sitting to the immediate left of V?
questions.explanation: After arranging the seats based on the given conditions, we find that S is to the immediate left of V. P and Q can be arranged such that P is second to the left of Q, while R and T are opposite. With U not next to T, the arrangement becomes clear.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Eight friends (A, B, C, D, E, F, G, and H) are sitting around a rectangular table with three on the longer sides and two on the shorter sides. They face inward. A sits at one of the shorter sides with E sitting opposite. C is not sitting at any corner. B and G are on the same side. H sits at a corner between F and G. Where does D sit?
questions.explanation: By arranging based on the conditions, D can only fit opposite B. E is opposite A on the shorter sides. C not being at a corner means it takes one of the mid-longer side positions, with B and G sharing a side. H at a corner between F and G fixes the positions.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Twelve people are sitting in a rectangular arrangement with four on each longer side and two on each shorter side. Some are facing inward while others outward. K is sitting opposite L, facing inside. M is sitting on the shorter side next to N, who is facing outside. O is two seats away from K. P sits opposite M. Who is sitting to the immediate left of K?
questions.explanation: Using the conditions, place K facing inward opposite L. M and P are opposite with N next to M. O is two seats from K and can be placed. After arranging, J is found to be to the left of K.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: At a hexagonal table with six people (X, Y, Z, A1, A2, and A3), X is facing the center. Y is two places to the left of Z. A2 sits opposite X. A3 is not next to Z. A1 is sitting directly opposite Y. Who sits immediately to the right of A2?
questions.explanation: Place X facing the center. A2 sits opposite X. With A1 directly opposite Y and Y two places from Z, resolve positions with A3 not next to Z. This places Z immediately to the right of A2.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Four friends, A, B, C, and D, are sitting at a square table with one person on each side. All are facing towards the center. A is sitting to the immediate left of B. C is not sitting opposite to A. Who is sitting opposite to D?
questions.explanation: Given the conditions: 1) A is to the immediate left of B. 2) C is not opposite A. Arrange them: A sits on one side, B on the next (immediate right), then D, and finally C on the last side. Hence, B sits opposite D.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Eight friends are sitting around a square table in such a way that there are two people on each side, and they are facing the center. P is sitting second to the left of Q. R is sitting opposite to Q. S is sitting next to P. Who is sitting to the immediate right of S?
questions.explanation: Positioning Q, R, and P based on the conditions, then S next to P, we find T is immediately right of S when facing the center.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Eight friends are sitting around a rectangular table with two on each long side and one on each short side. Everyone is facing the center. P and Q are sitting on the same side. R is sitting diagonally opposite to P. S is sitting next to R. T is sitting between P and Q. Who is sitting opposite to S?
questions.explanation: Following the seating arrangement logic and placing P, Q, and T on the same side, R diagonally opposite to P, we find V is directly opposite S.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Twelve people are sitting at a large rectangular table with three on each long side and two on each short side. Some are facing center and some are facing outward. A is sitting facing center and directly opposite B who faces outward. C is sitting to the right of A. D is diagonally opposite to E who is facing center. Who is sitting to the left of E?
questions.explanation: Placing A opposite B, and following other conditions to position C, D, E, etc., G is found to be to the left of E.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Twelve friends are sitting in a hexagonal arrangement, each at a corner or side. Some face inward, others outward. P sits at a corner facing inward. Q is two places left of P, facing outward. R sits opposite P. S and T sit facing each other. Who sits between R and Q?
questions.explanation: Arranging based on P's position, with Q two places left and R opposite, the sequence gives V sitting between R and Q.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Four friends, A, B, C, and D, sit at a square table, one person per side, all facing outward. Here are the conditions: 1) A sits opposite to B. 2) C sits to the left of D. Who sits to the right of A?
questions.explanation: Since A sits opposite B, they must be on opposite sides. C sits to the left of D, meaning when facing outward, if D is on the north side, C is on the west side. Hence, D must be to the right of A, making A sit on the south side and D on the west side.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Eight people: A, B, C, D, E, F, G, and H are sitting around a square table with two people on each side, some facing inward and some facing outward. The conditions are: 1) A sits on the corner facing inward. 2) C sits opposite to E. 3) D sits immediately left of E. 4) F sits between G and H. 5) A sits third to the right of F. Who sits to the immediate right of G?
questions.explanation: F sits between G and H, and A sits third to the right of F facing inward. After arranging based on these conditions and others, G sits opposite A, with H to the immediate right of G.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Eight friends: P, Q, R, S, T, U, V, and W are sitting in a square formation with two on each side, facing both inward and outward. The following conditions apply: 1) P sits directly opposite U, 2) R and T are neighbors but T faces inward and R faces outward, 3) Q sits to the left of S, 4) V is not facing the same direction as W. Where is V seated?
questions.explanation: Given the positions and directions, V must sit next to W. P opposite U and other conditions help place the others appropriately, confirming V next to W with opposite direction.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Twelve colleagues are seated around a rectangular table with three on each side. Some face inward, others outward. The clues are: 1) A sits exactly opposite D. 2) E sits to the immediate right of A. 3) G is opposite F but not at the corners. 4) B and C sit together facing the same direction. 5) H is to the left of J but both face opposite directions. Who sits directly opposite J?
questions.explanation: From the given conditions, B and C face the same direction next to each other. A is opposite D, meaning E is beside A. G and F are opposite on the longer side. With H to the left of J, D is opposite J.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Thirteen people: A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I, J, K, L, and M are arranged at a hexagonal table, two per side, facing either towards or away from the center. Conditions are: 1) A sits third to the right of B. 2) D is not a neighbor of A. 3) F and G sit together but face opposite directions. 4) E and I are exactly opposite. 5) K is between L and M, facing away from the center. Who sits to the immediate left of G?
questions.explanation: Using given clues, place each person by elimination. F and G are together; A sits third to the right of B; L and M must be on the same side as K. G has F to one side, making H to the left when facing outward.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Four friends, A, B, C, and D, are sitting at a square table with one person on each side, all facing the center. A sits on the north side. B sits opposite D. Who sits on the west side?
questions.explanation: Since A is on the north side, D must be on the south side (opposite A). B sits opposite D, so B is on the north side. Hence, C must sit on the west side.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Eight people - P, Q, R, S, T, U, V, and W - are sitting around a square table with two people on each side. Some are facing inward and some are facing outward. P sits second to the left of Q, who faces inward. R sits third to the right of P and faces outward. S, who faces inward, sits on the immediate left of R. U sits opposite V. W sits third to the left of T. Who sits to the immediate right of V?
questions.explanation: By processing the positions with given facing directions and ensuring oppositions, the arrangement leads to P sitting to the immediate right of V.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Seven friends - A, B, C, D, E, F, and G - are sitting around a triangular table with three seats per side and one corner empty. A sits at one corner, and C sits second to the left of A. G sits second to the right of C. D and B are neighbors, but neither is adjacent to A. F sits at a corner. Who is sitting at the empty corner?
questions.explanation: Determining positions based on neighbor and corner constraints, B is found to be at the empty corner as others are arranged around the triangle.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Twelve people are sitting around a rectangular table with three people on each side. Facing directions are mixed. A and B are on the same side, with A facing inward and sitting to the immediate right of B. C is opposite B and faces outward. D sits diagonally opposite A. E sits at one of the corners and faces outward. F sits second to the right of E. G is sitting on the same side as F but faces inward. H sits opposite G and faces outward. Who sits immediately to the left of D?
questions.explanation: Using the configuration given and facing directions, E sits immediately to the left of D when arranged correctly around the table.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A hexagonal table has six people, one on each side, with mixed directions. Person 1 sits facing outward, opposite to Person 4. Person 2 sits to the immediate right of Person 1 and faces inward. Person 5 is opposite Person 6, who faces outward and sits to the immediate left of Person 3. Who is sitting two positions to the right of Person 2?
