questions.explanation: Arranging the people based on oppositions and immediate directions, Person 6 ends up being two positions to the right of Person 2.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Four friends, A, B, C, and D, are sitting at a square table, one on each side, facing the center. The following conditions apply: 1) A sits directly opposite B. 2) C sits to the right of D. 3) D is not sitting on the east side. Who is sitting on the north side?
questions.explanation: Since A sits opposite B, they can either be North-South or East-West. Given C is to the right of D and D is not on the east side, D must be on the west side and C on the north side. Thus, A and B must sit on the south and east sides respectively.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Eight people are seated around a square table, two per side, facing outward. Conditions: 1) M sits to the immediate left of N. 2) O sits opposite P. 3) Q is not adjacent to R. 4) S sits diagonally opposite T. 5) N sits on the west side. Who is directly opposite M?
questions.explanation: With N on the west and M immediately to N’s left, M must sit on the south side. O opposite P means they are on the east and west, or north and south. S opposite T allows M and N to be placed with S or T. The remaining arrangement with all conditions satisfied means P is opposite M.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Eight people sit at a rectangular table, four on each long side, all facing the center. Conditions: 1) U sits at one of the corners. 2) V sits opposite W. 3) X sits next to Y and is two seats away from Z. 4) U sits next to W but not next to X. Who is directly opposite to Y?
questions.explanation: U at a corner with V opposite W suggests a setup where W and U are on opposite sides with U next to W, but not X. This arrangement allows X and Y to sit together with W and U spaced accordingly, placing V directly opposite Y.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Twelve people are seated at a rectangular table, three on each side. Conditions: 1) A sits two seats away from B. 2) C is opposite D. 3) E is two seats away from F on the same side. 4) G is to the immediate left of H. 5) B is opposite I. 6) J is diagonally opposite K. Where does L sit in relation to G?
questions.explanation: The layout has A and B positioned with a gap, C opposite D, and arrangements placing E and F on the same side. G and H's position to each other allows B opposite I. With J and K diagonally positioned, L ends up two seats from G.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Sixteen people are seated at a hexagonal table, four on each side. Conditions: 1) M is opposite N. 2) O is two places to the right of P. 3) Q and R are diagonally opposite. 4) S sits directly opposite T. 5) U sits between V and W. 6) X is three places from Y. Which side does Z sit?
questions.explanation: The hexagonal setup requires logical placement where conditions 1-6 are met. Given opposites and diagonal placements, Z logically aligns on the same side as Y due to the three places condition with X and complex interdependencies with V, W, and U.
questions.subject: Reasoning

(2) Evaluation: I is valid as it directly follows from 60% preference. II is invalid as it suggests exclusivity, which is unsupported. III is valid since 60% of 1000 is 600. (3) Conclusion: Inferences I and III are valid.

questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statement: A recent survey revealed that 60% of the participants prefer working remotely, while 40% prefer working in the office. The survey also indicated that participants under 30 are more likely to prefer remote work compared to those over 30. 

Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement?

I. A majority of all participants prefer working remotely.
II. Age plays a role in the preference for remote work.
III. More than half of participants over 30 prefer working in the office.

options.C: Only inferences I and II are valid
options.D: Only inferences II and III are valid

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) Key facts: 60% prefer remote work, those under 30 are more likely to prefer remote work than those over 30. (2) Inference I is valid because 60% indicates a majority prefer remote work. (3) Inference II is valid since there is a correlation between age and work preference stated. (4) Inference III is unprovable since it is not explicitly stated what percentage of those over 30 prefer office work. (5) Conclusion: Only inferences I and II are valid.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statement: An international study found that countries with higher education expenditures tend to have higher literacy rates. However, literacy rates did not increase in countries that spent more on higher education but lacked quality educational infrastructure.

Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement?

I. Spending on education is not the only factor affecting literacy rates.
II. Countries with good educational infrastructure and high expenditures are likely to have high literacy rates.
III. Higher education spending directly increases literacy rates.

options.C: Only inferences I and II are valid
options.D: Only inferences II and III are valid

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) Key facts: Education spending is correlated with literacy rates, but quality infrastructure is necessary. (2) Inference I is valid as spending is mentioned as a factor but not the sole determinant. (3) Inference II is valid because the statement implies that good infrastructure is important along with spending. (4) Inference III is invalid since the statement mentions no direct causal relationship without infrastructure. (5) Conclusion: Only inferences I and II are valid.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statement: A tech company reported that their new software update reduces app crashes by 30% and improves speed by 20%. However, some users reported no noticeable change in app performance.

Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement?

I. The software update is effective for all users.
II. The majority of users experience improved app performance after the update.
III. Some users did not benefit from the software update.

options.D: Only inferences II and III are valid

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) Key facts: The update claims to reduce crashes and improve speed, but not all users noticed changes. (2) Inference I is invalid because not all users reported improvements. (3) Inference II is unprovable as the statement does not specify the percentage of users experiencing improvements. (4) Inference III is valid as it's explicitly mentioned that some users saw no change. (5) Conclusion: Only inference III is valid.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statement: Studies show that regular physical exercise significantly reduces stress levels. However, individuals with chronic conditions found only a slight reduction in stress through exercise.

Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement?

I. Regular exercise always effectively reduces stress.
II. Exercise is less effective in reducing stress for individuals with chronic conditions.
III. Physical exercise is a means to reduce stress.

options.D: Only inferences II and III are valid

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) Key facts: Regular exercise reduces stress, but it's less effective for those with chronic conditions. (2) Inference I is invalid since exercise is not always effective, especially for chronic conditions. (3) Inference II is valid as explicitly stated in the passage. (4) Inference III is valid as the passage confirms exercise reduces stress. (5) Conclusion: Only inferences II and III are valid.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statement: According to a recent financial report, Company X's profits increased by 15% in the last quarter. This is attributed to an increase in sales in the domestic market, despite a reduction in international sales.

Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement?

I. Company X's domestic sales have increased.
II. The increase in profits is due to international sales.
III. The domestic market contributed positively to Company X's profitability.

options.D: Only inferences I and III are valid

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) Key facts: Profits increased due to domestic sales, while international sales decreased. (2) Inference I is valid because the increase in profits is attributed to domestic sales. (3) Inference II is invalid as international sales actually decreased. (4) Inference III is valid since domestic sales were responsible for the profit increase. (5) Conclusion: Only inferences I and III are valid.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Statement: The company announced that all employees who have worked for more than ten years will receive a special bonus as a token of appreciation for their loyalty. Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement? I. Employees who have not completed ten years are not eligible for the bonus. II. The company values long-term employee loyalty. III. Every employee will receive the bonus.

options.C: Only inferences I and II are valid
options.D: Only inferences II and III are valid

questions.explanation: (1) The statement explicitly mentions the criteria for receiving the bonus, which is working more than ten years. (2) Inference I is valid as it directly follows the exclusion criterion given. (3) Inference II is valid as announcing a bonus for loyalty suggests valuing it. (4) Inference III is not valid as the statement specifies only those who have completed ten years, not all employees.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Statement: A recent study indicates that individuals who exercise at least 30 minutes a day are less likely to develop chronic illnesses compared to those who do not engage in regular physical activity. Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement? I. Exercising for 30 minutes daily prevents all chronic illnesses. II. Not exercising regularly may increase the risk of chronic illnesses. III. Regular physical activity is beneficial for health.

options.C: Only inferences II and III are valid
options.D: Only inferences I and II are valid

questions.explanation: (1) The statement provides data showing a correlation between regular exercise and lower likelihood of chronic illnesses. (2) Inference I is invalid as the statement does not claim complete prevention of illnesses. (3) Inference II is valid because the absence of exercise is linked to higher risk. (4) Inference III is valid as the data supports the health benefits of regular physical activity.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Statement: The new policy mandates that all new hires must undergo a comprehensive training program to improve work efficiency and reduce errors. Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement? I. Current employees are not required to undergo the training program. II. The company has experienced issues with work efficiency and errors. III. Only new hires will benefit from the training program.

options.C: Only inferences I and II are valid
options.D: Only inferences II and III are valid

questions.explanation: (1) The statement specifies the policy for new hires but does not mention current employees, so inference I is unprovable. (2) Inference II is valid as the policy aims to improve efficiency and reduce errors, indicating existing issues. (3) Inference III is not valid since the statement does not exclude others from potentially benefiting.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Statement: An analysis of global economic data from the past decade shows that countries with high levels of technological innovation tend to have higher GDP growth rates. Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement? I. Technological innovation directly causes GDP growth. II. Countries with low technological innovation have lower GDP growth rates. III. There is a correlation between technological innovation and GDP growth.

options.C: Only inferences II and III are valid

questions.explanation: (1) The statement identifies a correlation but does not prove causation, making inference I invalid. (2) While the analysis suggests a trend, inference II is not definitively supported without specific data on low innovation. (3) Inference III is valid as the statement explicitly states a correlation between the factors.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Statement: A report on urban traffic patterns concludes that cities which have invested heavily in public transportation infrastructure face fewer traffic congestions during peak hours compared to those that have not made such investments. Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement? I. Public transportation is a solution to traffic congestion. II. Cities without investments in public transportation always face traffic congestion. III. Investing in public transportation can reduce traffic congestion during peak hours.

options.C: Only inferences I and III are valid

questions.explanation: (1) The statement indicates a correlation between investment in public transportation and reduced congestion, supporting inference I. (2) Inference II is not valid as the statement does not claim that cities always face congestion without investment. (3) Inference III is valid as it is directly supported by the statement's correlation between investment and reduced congestion.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statement: A recent survey revealed that 70% of urban residents prefer online shopping over visiting physical stores. However, 60% of rural residents still favor physical shopping due to limited internet access and trust issues with online platforms.

Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement?

I. Urban residents generally have better internet access than rural residents.
II. Trust issues are a significant factor in rural residents' preference for physical shopping.
III. The majority of the population prefers online shopping.

options.C: Only inferences I and II are valid
options.D: Only inferences II and III are valid

questions.explanation: (1) The statement highlights the preference trends in urban versus rural populations regarding shopping methods. (2) Inference I is valid as the statement implies that internet access is a differentiating factor. Inference II is supported by the statement as it explicitly mentions trust issues. Inference III is incorrect as the statement does not provide conclusive data about the majority of the entire population, only urban and rural splits. (3) Therefore, inferences I and II are definitely true based on the statement.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statement: The city council implemented a policy requiring all new commercial buildings to include solar panels. Within two years, the city's carbon emissions from these buildings dropped by 15%.

Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement?

I. The installation of solar panels directly led to the reduction in carbon emissions.
II. The policy was effective in reducing the carbon footprint of commercial buildings.
III. Other factors, besides solar panels, could have contributed to the decrease in emissions.

options.C: Only inferences I and II are valid
options.D: Only inferences II and III are valid

questions.explanation: (1) The statement provides a correlation between the policy and the reduction in emissions. (2) Inference I is not valid as the statement does not establish a direct causal link, only a correlation. Inference II is valid as the policy's effectiveness is evident through the measurable reduction in emissions. Inference III is plausible, but not definitely true from the information provided; it is an assumption about possible other factors. (3) Thus, only inference II is a valid deduction from the statement.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statement: A study found that students who study late at night score higher in exams than those who study early in the morning. However, this study only considered students from a single university and did not account for differences in subject matter difficulty or individual student habits.

Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement?

I. Studying late at night is more effective for academic performance than studying in the morning.
II. The results of the study cannot be generalized to all students.
III. Factors other than study time could influence academic performance.

options.D: Only inferences II and III are valid

questions.explanation: (1) The statement presents a specific study with limitations. (2) Inference I is invalid since the study lacks comprehensive data and does not account for various influencing factors; thus, the effectiveness of study time cannot be definitively concluded. Inference II is valid as the study's scope is limited to one university, preventing generalization. Inference III is valid because the study's acknowledgment of not considering other factors implies their potential impact on results. (3) Therefore, only inferences II and III are definitely true.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statement: The company's quarterly financial report indicated a 20% increase in revenue compared to the previous quarter. The report attributes this growth to the successful launch of a new product line, despite an overall downturn in the industry.

Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement?

I. The new product line has been well-received in the market.
II. The company is outperforming the industry trend.
III. The increased revenue is solely due to the new product line.

options.C: Only inferences I and II are valid
options.D: Only inferences II and III are valid

questions.explanation: (1) The statement provides specific details about the company's financial performance and the industry context. (2) Inference I is valid as the product's success is mentioned as a key factor for increased revenue. Inference II is also valid because the company has grown despite industry downturns, indicating outperformance. Inference III is invalid as the statement does not claim the new product line is the sole reason for revenue increase, only a contributing factor. (3) Thus, inferences I and II are definitely true.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statement: The local park recently introduced a fitness trail that includes various workout stations. Since its inauguration, park attendance has increased by 25%.

Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement?

I. The fitness trail is the main reason for the increase in park attendance.
II. More people are engaging in fitness activities in the park.
III. The park was less attractive to visitors before the fitness trail was added.

options.D: Only inferences II and III are valid

questions.explanation: (1) The statement notes an increase in park attendance following the introduction of a fitness trail. (2) Inference I is invalid as the statement does not specify the trail as the sole reason for increased attendance. Inference II is valid because the presence of workout stations implies increased engagement in fitness activities. Inference III is an assumption not supported by the statement; increased attractiveness is not necessarily implied. (3) Thus, only inference II can be definitely concluded from the statement.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statement: A recent survey reports that 70% of urban residents prefer online shopping over traditional shopping due to convenience and variety, while 20% still prefer the personal experience of visiting stores. 10% have no preference.

Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement?

I. A majority of urban residents find online shopping more convenient.
II. Traditional shopping is considered less convenient by the surveyed urban residents.
III. Some urban residents do not have a preference for either shopping method.

options.C: Only inferences I and II are valid
options.D: Only inferences I and III are valid

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) The key fact is that 70% prefer online shopping for convenience, 20% prefer traditional shopping for the experience, and 10% have no preference. (2) Evaluation: I is true because 70% (majority) find it more convenient. II is not definitely true because the statement doesn't confirm what is less convenient, just why they prefer online shopping. III is true because 10% have no preference. (3) Therefore, inferences I and III are valid.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statement: According to a study, companies that implemented a four-day workweek reported a 20% increase in productivity, while employee satisfaction ratings improved by 30%. However, some businesses noted challenges in maintaining customer service levels.

Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement?

I. A four-day workweek can lead to increased employee satisfaction.
II. All companies that adopted a four-day workweek saw improved customer service.
III. Some companies may face issues with customer service under a four-day workweek.

options.C: Only inferences I and III are valid
options.D: Only inferences II and III are valid

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) Key facts include a 20% productivity increase, 30% satisfaction improvement, and some companies facing customer service challenges. (2) Evaluation: I is valid due to the 30% satisfaction increase. II is invalid as the statement mentions some companies facing challenges, indicating not all improved. III is valid as 'some businesses noted challenges' implies issues exist. (3) Inferences I and III are valid.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statement: In the latest financial quarter, Company X reported a 10% increase in revenues but a 5% decrease in net profits compared to the previous quarter. The management attributed this to higher operating expenses during the period.

Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement?

I. Company X's operating expenses increased in the latest quarter.
II. Despite increased revenues, Company X's profitability declined.
III. The decrease in net profits was due to factors other than operating expenses.

options.C: Only inferences I and II are valid
options.D: Only inferences II and III are valid

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) Key facts are revenue increase, profit decrease, and high operating expenses. (2) Evaluation: I is valid because management directly attributed profit decline to higher operating expenses. II is valid as increased revenues are mentioned alongside decreased profitability. III is not supported as the statement attributes the profit decline to operating expenses. (3) Inferences I and II are valid.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statement: A comprehensive study on climate change showed that regions experiencing more than a 2-degree increase in average temperature saw a 15% decline in agricultural yield, while regions with less than a 2-degree rise reported stable agricultural outputs.

Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement?

I. A rise in temperature above 2 degrees adversely affects agricultural yield.
II. Stable agricultural outputs are guaranteed if temperature rises are below 2 degrees.
III. Temperature increases have no effect on agriculture if under 2 degrees.

options.C: Only inferences I and II are valid

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) The study details a 15% decline in yield with over 2-degree rises, and stability under 2 degrees. (2) Evaluation: I is valid as the decline directly correlates with >2-degree rises. II is not valid because 'stable' does not guarantee unchangeable outputs, only that they haven't changed, and there is no guarantee for the future. III is invalid because 'stable' doesn't confirm no effect, merely no change was observed. (3) Only inference I is valid.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statement: An experiment conducted on nocturnal animals showed that a decrease in night light intensity by 30% resulted in increased foraging activity. However, the study also noted an increase in predation risks for these animals under reduced lighting.

Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement?

I. Nocturnal animals forage more when it is darker.
II. Reduced lighting always increases predation risks for nocturnal animals.
III. Increased foraging activity in low light is linked with higher predation risks.

options.C: Only inferences I and III are valid
options.D: Only inferences II and III are valid

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) Key points are increased foraging with reduced light and linked predation risks. (2) Evaluation: I is valid as increased foraging was observed with reduced light. II is invalid because the statement doesn't claim 'always', only observed increased risk in this study. III is valid as the study notes an increase in predation risks associated with increased foraging under reduced light conditions. (3) Inferences I and III are valid.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statement: A recent study found that 60% of people who regularly exercise have lower stress levels compared to those who do not engage in any physical activity.

Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement?

I. Regular exercise contributes to lower stress levels.
II. People who do not exercise regularly are always stressed.
III. More than half of regular exercisers have lower stress levels.

options.C: Only inferences I and III are valid
options.D: Only inferences II and III are valid

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) The study provides data showing a correlation between regular exercise and lower stress levels, indicating a significant portion of regular exercisers experience reduced stress. (2) Inference I is supported by the data as it states a correlation shown by the study. (3) Inference II is invalid because the statement does not claim that all non-exercisers are stressed, just that they are less likely to have lower stress levels. (4) Inference III is valid because the study explicitly states that 60% of regular exercisers have lower stress levels.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statement: According to a government report, the unemployment rate fell by 2% last year, and the job market for technology professionals grew by 5% in the same period.

Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement?

I. The decline in unemployment is solely due to the growth of technology jobs.
II. The overall job market improved last year.
III. Technology jobs contributed to reducing the unemployment rate.

options.D: Only inferences II and III are valid

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) The statement provides data on unemployment rates and the growth of technology jobs. (2) Inference I is invalid as the statement does not claim technology jobs are the sole cause of the decline. (3) Inference II is valid because a reduction in unemployment generally indicates an improvement in the job market. (4) Inference III is valid as technology jobs are part of the employment landscape and their growth likely contributed to the decrease in unemployment.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statement: A survey conducted among urban residents showed that 70% prefer online shopping due to convenience, while 30% still favor physical stores due to the ability to physically assess the products.

Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement?

I. A significant majority of urban residents find online shopping more convenient.
II. Online shopping is universally considered better than physical shopping.
III. A minority of the respondents appreciate the tactile experience offered by physical stores.

options.D: Only inferences I and III are valid

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) The statement describes preferences of urban residents regarding shopping methods. (2) Inference I is valid since 70% is a significant majority. (3) Inference II is invalid because the statement only indicates preference percentages, not universal superiority. (4) Inference III is valid as 30% represent a minority who value the tactile experience, in line with the survey results.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statement: An analysis of financial records of multiple companies reveals that those investing in employee well-being programs saw a 15% increase in productivity, while others saw a static productivity rate.

Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement?

I. Employee well-being programs are linked to increased productivity.
II. Companies not investing in well-being programs will never see a productivity increase.
III. Investment in employee well-being is the only factor contributing to increased productivity.

options.D: Only inferences I and II are valid
options.E: None of the inferences are valid

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) The statement provides data correlating well-being programs with productivity increases. (2) Inference I is valid as the data explicitly links the two. (3) Inference II is invalid because the data doesn’t indicate future possibilities for companies without such programs. (4) Inference III is invalid because the statement does not claim well-being programs are the only factor.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Statement: Despite the introduction of electric buses, the city's overall carbon emissions did not decrease last year due to an increase in private car usage.

Which of the following inference(s) can be definitely drawn from the above statement?

I. Electric buses alone are insufficient to reduce overall carbon emissions.
II. The increase in private car usage offset the reduction achieved by electric buses.
III. Other factors besides private car usage contributed to stable carbon emissions.

options.C: Only inference I and II are valid
options.D: Only inference II and III are valid

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) The statement explains why carbon emissions did not decrease despite electric buses. (2) Inference I is valid as the unchanged emissions indicate electric buses alone were not enough. (3) Inference II is valid because the statement directly attributes the lack of emission reduction to increased private car usage. (4) Inference III is invalid as the statement does not mention any other factors impacting emissions.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
A local bakery claims that their new gluten-free bread is as nutritious as their regular whole grain bread, as it contains similar levels of fiber and vitamins. However, sales have decreased since the introduction of the new product. The bakery concludes that their customers do not care about nutritional content when choosing bread.

Which of the following, if true, most weakens the argument?

options.A: The gluten-free bread is priced higher than the regular whole grain bread.
options.B: Customers of the bakery are more interested in taste than nutritional content.
options.C: The gluten-free bread is sold in smaller loaves than the regular whole grain bread.
options.D: A survey shows that a significant number of customers have allergies to gluten.
options.E: The regular whole grain bread has been on sale at a discount since the new product launch.

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) The conclusion is that customers do not care about nutritional content. (2) The assumption is that sales decrease is due to lack of interest in nutrition. (3) Option E weakens this by suggesting another reason for the sales drop—price competition, not indifference to nutrition. (4) Other options either support different causes or do not address the primary sales decrease issue directly.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
A study claims that people who exercise regularly are less likely to suffer from depression. The researchers conclude that exercising directly reduces the likelihood of depression.

Which of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?

options.A: People who are already depressed are less likely to start exercising.
options.B: Regular exercise increases the production of endorphins, which are known to improve mood.
options.C: The study only included participants who were already physically healthy.
options.D: People who exercise regularly also tend to have healthier diets.
options.E: The study found that people who do yoga, a form of exercise, have lower rates of depression.

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) The conclusion is that exercising reduces depression risk. (2) The assumption is that exercise has a direct causal link to reduced depression. (3) Option B strengthens by providing a biological mechanism (endorphins) explaining the link. (4) Other options either discuss correlates of exercise or potential biases in the study.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
A technology company claims that its new data encryption method is unbreakable, based on tests showing it took experts significantly longer to attempt to breach it than other systems. The company concludes it provides the highest level of security available.

Which of the following, if true, most weakens the argument?

options.A: The tests did not simulate real-world hacking attempts that exploit human error.
options.B: Other companies have also developed similar encryption methods recently.
options.C: The experts used in the tests were not informed about updates in encryption technology.
options.D: The tests were conducted using outdated computer systems.
options.E: Some experts argue that no encryption can be truly unbreakable.

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) The conclusion claims the method is the highest security due to test difficulty. (2) Assumes tests reflect real-world security efficacy. (3) Option A weakens by showing tests don't account for real-world vulnerabilities like human error, questioning method's true security. (4) Other options either challenge the notion of unbreakability or question comparability without undermining test relevance.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
A recent government report concludes that the introduction of a new tax on sugary drinks will reduce sugar consumption significantly. This conclusion is based on the premise that higher prices will deter purchases.

All of the following weaken the argument EXCEPT:

options.A: Some consumers may switch to buying sugary drinks in bulk from places with lower prices.
options.B: People may replace sugary drinks with other high-sugar foods.
options.C: Surveys indicate that only a small percentage of people consider price when choosing drinks.
options.D: The tax revenue is being used to subsidize healthier food options, increasing their consumption.
options.E: Past attempts to reduce sugar consumption through education campaigns were ineffective.

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) The conclusion is that tax will reduce sugar consumption. (2) Assumes price increases lead to behavior change. (3) Option D doesn't weaken because it supports positive outcomes from tax revenue, indirectly supporting healthier choices. (4) Other options provide alternative behaviors or suggest price insensitivity.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
A pharmaceutical company claims that their new drug reduces the risk of heart attacks by 50% based on a clinical trial. The trial was conducted on individuals aged 60 and above who have a history of heart disease.

Which of the following, if true, casts the most doubt on the company's claim?

options.A: Participants in the trial also followed a strict diet and exercise regimen.
options.B: The trial only lasted for six months, making long-term effects unknown.
options.C: The drug was found to have significant side effects in some participants.
options.D: The reduction in heart attacks was similar across different age groups in the study.
options.E: A significant number of participants were taking other medications for heart disease during the trial.

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) Conclusion is drug reduces heart attack risk by 50%. (2) Assumes reduction is due to the drug alone. (3) Option A introduces a confounding factor (diet and exercise), suggesting the trial's results may not solely be attributed to the drug, thus weakening the claim. (4) Other options either focus on different issues or do not directly challenge the drug's attributed effectiveness.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A recent study shows that people who consume at least one cup of green tea per day are 20% less likely to develop cardiovascular diseases compared to those who do not consume green tea. Therefore, drinking green tea is a significant preventive measure against cardiovascular diseases. Which of the following, if true, most weakens the argument?

options.A: The study did not account for participants' overall diet and exercise habits.
options.B: The study was conducted over a period of ten years.
options.C: Green tea contains antioxidants that are beneficial to heart health.
options.D: Participants who drank green tea also showed a lower incidence of stress-related disorders.
options.E: Many participants in the study were already at low risk for cardiovascular diseases.

questions.explanation: The argument concludes that drinking green tea is a preventive measure against cardiovascular diseases based on a correlation found in a study. The assumption is that green tea directly contributes to this health benefit. Option A weakens the argument by introducing the possibility that other factors like diet and exercise, which were not accounted for in the study, could have influenced the results. This exposes a flaw in the causal link the argument depends on. Other options either do not address this assumption or are irrelevant to the causal claim.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A company claims that its new marketing strategy, which involves increased social media engagement, has led to a 30% increase in sales over the past quarter. Which of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?

options.A: The company also introduced a major discount campaign during the same period.
options.B: Other companies in the industry did not show a similar increase in sales.
options.C: The company's social media followers increased by 50% over the past quarter.
options.D: Customer satisfaction ratings have remained unchanged despite the sales increase.
options.E: The company's product range was expanded to include more popular items.

questions.explanation: The conclusion is that the new marketing strategy involving social media engagement directly caused the sales increase. The key assumption is that this strategy, rather than other factors, led to the increase. Option B strengthens the argument by eliminating the possibility that the sales increase was due to broader industry trends, thereby supporting the specific impact of the company's strategy. Other options either introduce confounding factors or are irrelevant to the causal claim.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A government report argues that the introduction of new stringent emission standards for vehicles will lead to a significant reduction in urban air pollution levels within five years. Which of the following, if true, most weakens the argument?

options.A: Many automobile manufacturers are already producing vehicles that meet these new standards.
options.B: Urban air pollution levels have been decreasing steadily over the past decade.
options.C: The new standards apply only to newly manufactured vehicles, not to those already in use.
options.D: Other countries that implemented similar standards saw a reduction in pollution levels.
options.E: The standards include stricter limits on both carbon emissions and particulate matter.

questions.explanation: The argument assumes that the introduction of new emission standards will directly lead to reduced pollution levels. However, Option C weakens the argument by highlighting that the standards do not affect existing vehicles, which may continue to contribute significantly to pollution. This undermines the conclusion that the policy will have a substantial impact on overall pollution levels. Other options either provide supporting information or are unrelated to the central assumption.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A recent study concludes that children who play musical instruments perform better academically than those who do not. The study suggests that music training enhances cognitive abilities and discipline. Which of the following, if true, most weakens the study's conclusion?

options.A: Children who play musical instruments are more likely to come from families that prioritize education.
options.B: The study involved children from various cultural backgrounds.
options.C: Music training has been shown to improve hand-eye coordination.
options.D: The study found no difference in the academic performance of children who played different types of musical instruments.
options.E: The benefits of music training were observed regardless of the duration of practice.

questions.explanation: The conclusion is that playing musical instruments enhances academic performance through improved cognitive abilities and discipline. The assumption is that music training, rather than other factors, is responsible for the better academic performance. Option A weakens the conclusion by suggesting that the correlation might be due to socioeconomic factors, as children from education-focused families may have more support or resources for academic success, independent of music training. Other options either support the conclusion or are irrelevant to the central assumption.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A health organization claims that a new drug reduces the risk of a particular type of cancer by up to 40%. However, some critics argue that the drug's long-term effects are unknown. Which of the following, if true, most strengthens the health organization's claim?

options.A: The drug has been tested only on individuals who have a family history of cancer.
options.B: The drug works by targeting specific cancerous cells without affecting healthy cells.
options.C: Long-term studies are underway but have yet to be completed.
options.D: The drug is effective in reducing the risk of several other types of cancer.
options.E: The reduction in cancer risk was observed only in people who took the drug consistently for more than a year.

questions.explanation: The argument claims that the new drug significantly reduces the risk of cancer. The key assumption is that the drug effectively targets cancerous cells and does so safely. Option B strengthens the argument by providing a mechanism through which the drug achieves its effects without harming healthy cells, thus making the claim more credible. Other options either introduce limitations or are irrelevant to the central claim.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
A new policy at a manufacturing plant aims to increase productivity by shortening the lunch break from 60 minutes to 30 minutes, arguing that this will reduce downtime and improve overall output.

Which of the following, if true, most weakens the argument?

options.A: Employees work more efficiently when they take shorter breaks.
options.B: The majority of employees use their lunch break to recharge, improving their performance in the afternoon.
options.C: The plant has previously increased productivity by implementing new technology.
options.D: Shorter breaks are likely to reduce employee morale and satisfaction.
options.E: Productivity has increased in other plants with similar break policies.

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) Conclusion: Shortening lunch breaks will increase productivity. Premises: Shorter lunch breaks lead to less downtime. (2) Assumption: Employees' productivity is not adversely affected by shorter breaks. (3) Option B provides evidence that contradicts this by showing that longer breaks improve afternoon performance, thus weakening the argument. (4) Other options do not directly address the impact of break length on productivity.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
A recent study claims that a new drug reduces the risk of heart disease by 30%. However, the study was conducted on a group of male participants aged 50-60. The pharmaceutical company states that the drug will be equally effective for all adults.

Which of the following, if true, most weakens the pharmaceutical company’s claim?

options.A: The drug was also tested on a younger group with similar results.
options.B: Women have different risk factors for heart disease compared to men.
options.C: Older adults are more compliant with medication regimes than younger adults.
options.D: The study did not account for participants' lifestyle choices.
options.E: The drug was more expensive than existing alternatives.

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) Conclusion: The drug is equally effective for all adults. Premises: Study shows effectiveness in males aged 50-60. (2) Assumption: Results are generalizable to all adults. (3) Option B introduces a gender-specific difference that questions the universality of the claim, thereby weakening the company's statement. (4) Other options don't directly address the issue of generalizability.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
A company's report states that introducing a flexible working environment has led to increased employee productivity. The report claims that allowing employees to choose their working hours results in better work-life balance and higher job satisfaction, thereby boosting productivity.

Which of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?

options.A: Employees who work the same hours every day are more productive than those with flexible schedules.
options.B: Departments with strict working hours have reported decreased productivity over the same period.
options.C: Flexible work schedules have made it harder for teams to coordinate on projects.
options.D: The company's overall revenue has remained unchanged since the implementation of flexible schedules.
options.E: Competitors without flexible schedules have also reported increased productivity.

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) Conclusion: Flexible working increases productivity. Premises: Flexible hours improve work-life balance and satisfaction. (2) Assumption: Flexible hours causally link to productivity improvements. (3) Option B supports this assumption by showing a productivity decline in departments without flexible schedules, thereby strengthening the argument. (4) Other options do not directly support the causal link between flexibility and productivity.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
A climate change model predicts that increasing carbon taxes will significantly reduce carbon emissions by discouraging the use of fossil fuels. The model assumes that consumers and businesses will switch to renewable energy sources as costs for fossil fuels rise.

Which of the following, if true, most weakens the argument?

options.A: Some businesses are investing in carbon capture technologies to offset emissions.
options.B: The initial cost of switching to renewable energy sources is prohibitively high for many businesses.
options.C: Government subsidies for renewable energy will decrease over the next decade.
options.D: The model does not account for global carbon emissions from non-taxed countries.
options.E: Renewable energy sources are becoming cheaper and more efficient.

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) Conclusion: Carbon taxes will reduce emissions. Premises: Taxes will lead to a shift to renewables. (2) Assumption: Switching to renewables is financially feasible. (3) Option B challenges this by highlighting the prohibitive costs, thus weakening the argument by undermining the feasibility of switching. (4) Other options do not directly contradict the assumption that taxes will lead to a switch to renewables.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
An education board has implemented a new teaching method, arguing that it will improve students' critical thinking skills. The method emphasizes problem-solving and interactive learning. However, some educators argue that traditional methods focusing on rote learning have their own benefits.

Which of the following, if true, would most weaken the board’s argument?

options.A: Students in experimental classes report enjoying learning more under the new method.
options.B: Standardized test scores have shown no significant difference between the new and traditional methods.
options.C: The new method increases classroom engagement and participation.
options.D: Parents have expressed satisfaction with the new teaching approach.
options.E: Research shows that interactive learning improves retention of complex concepts.

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) Conclusion: The new method will improve critical thinking. Premises: It focuses on problem-solving and interaction. (2) Assumption: The new method leads to better learning outcomes. (3) Option B undermines this assumption by showing no improvement in test scores, thereby weakening the argument. (4) Other options highlight benefits that do not directly address the claim about critical thinking skills.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A city council claims that installing more streetlights in dark areas of the city will significantly reduce crime rates. The council's proposal is based on a study showing that well-lit areas have lower crime rates compared to poorly lit areas. Which of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?

options.A: Streetlights are cost-effective and can be quickly installed in most areas.
options.B: Criminals tend to avoid areas that are well-lit because they fear being identified.
options.C: Most crimes in the city occur during daylight hours.
options.D: Some well-lit areas still experience high crime rates.
options.E: The city council has previously succeeded with a different crime reduction program.

questions.explanation: (1) Conclusion: Installing more streetlights will reduce crime rates. (2) Premises: Well-lit areas have lower crime rates. (3) Key Assumption: Criminals avoid well-lit areas. (4) Option B strengthens by supporting this assumption. Other options either do not address the key assumption or are irrelevant.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A new study suggests that implementing a four-day workweek can improve employee productivity. The study observed that employees working four days a week produced as much work as those on a traditional five-day schedule. However, the study participants were all volunteers from the same company. Which of the following, if true, most weakens the argument?

options.A: The company that participated in the study typically has a higher productivity level than the industry average.
options.B: Employees in other companies have reported similar increases in productivity with a four-day workweek.
options.C: The majority of the volunteers were already among the company's top performers.
options.D: The company plans to expand the four-day workweek pilot to include more departments.
options.E: The study only measured productivity without considering employee satisfaction.

questions.explanation: (1) Conclusion: A four-day workweek improves productivity. (2) Premises: Similar productivity levels in four vs. five days. (3) Key Assumption: Results are generalizable. (4) Option C weakens by showing volunteers are not representative of the general workforce. Other options are less relevant to the generalizability issue.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A recent report states that companies using a particular type of customer relationship management (CRM) software have seen a 20% increase in sales. The report suggests adopting this CRM software as a strategy for boosting sales across the industry. Which of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?

options.A: The CRM software is more expensive than competitors but offers more features.
options.B: Companies that adopted the software also invested heavily in staff training and customer support enhancements.
options.C: The CRM software has won several awards for its ease of use and functionality.
options.D: Most companies that did not see a sales increase had not implemented the software correctly.
options.E: The CRM software includes unique analytics tools that help target customer needs effectively.

questions.explanation: (1) Conclusion: Adopting the CRM software boosts sales. (2) Premises: 20% sales increase reported. (3) Key Assumption: The software directly contributes to the sales increase. (4) Option E strengthens by identifying a direct benefit of the software that explains the sales increase. Other options provide less direct support.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A government report claims that raising the minimum wage will lead to an overall increase in consumer spending, thereby boosting the economy. This conclusion is based on data showing higher income workers tend to spend more. Critics argue that the increase could lead to job losses. Which of the following, if true, would most weaken the government's argument?

options.A: Most businesses plan to absorb the additional wage costs without reducing their workforce.
options.B: Studies show that consumer spending does not significantly increase with small wage hikes.
options.C: The report failed to consider that some industries may face greater wage cost burdens than others.
options.D: Inflation is expected to rise, negating any potential spending increases from wage hikes.
options.E: The majority of minimum wage workers are employed in sectors unlikely to reduce spending following wage increases.

questions.explanation: (1) Conclusion: Raising minimum wage boosts economy via increased spending. (2) Premises: Higher income leads to more spending. (3) Key Assumption: Wage increase significantly impacts spending. (4) Option B weakens by showing that spending does not rise significantly with wage hikes. Other options address secondary issues or provide less direct counterevidence.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A study indicates that students who study with background music tend to have higher test scores compared to those who study in silence. The researchers conclude that background music enhances learning. Which of the following, if true, would cast the most doubt on the study's conclusion?

options.A: Students who listen to music while studying also tend to study longer hours.
options.B: The music used in the study was specifically chosen to be non-distracting.
options.C: There is no significant difference in test scores when comparing students who prefer different genres of music.
options.D: Many students reported feeling more relaxed and focused when studying with music.
options.E: Schools that banned music in study areas saw no improvement in student performance.

questions.explanation: (1) Conclusion: Background music enhances learning. (2) Premises: Higher test scores with music. (3) Key Assumption: Music directly influences learning positively. (4) Option A weakens by suggesting that longer study hours, not music, may explain score improvements. Other options either support the premise or are less relevant.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
A new city policy mandates that all public parks must close by 8 PM to reduce vandalism. The city council argues that since most vandalism occurs at night, closing parks early will significantly decrease these incidents.

Which of the following, if true, most weakens the argument?

options.A: Vandalism in parks predominantly occurs between 6 PM and 8 PM.
options.B: Nearby towns that close parks early have seen a rise in vandalism.
options.C: The majority of park visitors prefer using the park after 8 PM.
options.D: A recent survey indicates that park vandalism is more related to lack of security personnel than park hours.
options.E: Reports show that lighting improvements reduce park vandalism.

questions.explanation: The argument concludes that closing parks early will reduce vandalism based on the premise that vandalism occurs at night. Option D weakens the argument by suggesting that vandalism is more related to insufficient security rather than the park's operating hours. Other options do not directly address the assumption or provide alternative explanations that weaken the argument.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
A recent study found that children who play musical instruments tend to perform better in mathematics. The researchers conclude that learning a musical instrument enhances cognitive skills that improve mathematical ability.

Which of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?

options.A: Schools that prioritize music education report higher overall academic performance.
options.B: Children who excel in mathematics often have parents who are highly involved in their education.
options.C: The study did not account for children's socioeconomic status, which affects access to musical instruments.
options.D: A separate study shows that students who play sports also perform better in mathematics.
options.E: Children who play musical instruments also spend more time on extracurricular activities unrelated to academics.

questions.explanation: The conclusion is that playing musical instruments enhances cognitive skills that improve math performance. Option A strengthens this argument by suggesting a broader correlation between music education and overall academic success, implying that music may indeed contribute to cognitive development. Other options either introduce alternative factors or lack relevance to the specific causal link being evaluated.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
A tech company claims that implementing a four-day work week has increased productivity among its employees. They argue that this schedule leads to better work-life balance and less burnout.

Which of the following, if true, most weakens the argument?

options.A: Employees report feeling more energized with an extra day off each week.
options.B: Productivity measurements were taken during a seasonal slump when workload was lower.
options.C: Other companies with similar policies have reported mixed results in productivity.
options.D: The four-day work week has become a popular topic in management studies.
options.E: Some employees use the extra day off to pursue personal interests unrelated to work.

questions.explanation: The argument is that a four-day work week increases productivity due to better work-life balance. Option B weakens the argument by indicating that productivity measurements might not be reliable due to timing during a seasonal slump, suggesting that the perceived productivity increase might not be due to the policy change. Other options do not directly challenge the causal link between the four-day work week and increased productivity.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
A pharmaceutical company claims that its new drug reduces the duration of the common cold by 30%. The claim is based on a study where participants who took the drug reported feeling better in a shorter time compared to those who took a placebo.

Which of the following, if true, would cast the most doubt on the conclusion?

options.A: Participants in the study who took the placebo reported feeling better after consuming hot beverages.
options.B: The study found no significant difference in cold duration between male and female participants.
options.C: The drug was administered along with a high-dose vitamin regimen.
options.D: Participants were more likely to report symptoms honestly when taking the new drug.
options.E: The drug's price is significantly higher than that of other cold remedies.

questions.explanation: The conclusion is that the new drug reduces the duration of the common cold by 30%. Option C weakens the argument by suggesting that the vitamin regimen could have contributed to the perceived reduction in symptoms, thus introducing an alternative explanation. Other options do not directly challenge the claim about the drug's effectiveness.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
A city introduces a new tax on sugary drinks, claiming it will reduce the consumption of unhealthy beverages and improve public health outcomes.

Which of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?

options.A: The tax revenue will be used to fund public health campaigns.
options.B: In similar cities, sugary drink consumption declined significantly after a tax was implemented.
options.C: The cost of sugary drinks remains affordable despite the tax.
options.D: Most residents are unaware of the health risks associated with sugary drink consumption.
options.E: The local government plans to review the tax policy annually.

questions.explanation: The argument claims that a sugary drink tax will reduce consumption and improve public health. Option B strengthens the argument by providing evidence from similar cities where such a tax led to a decline in consumption, supporting the causal link between the tax and reduced unhealthy beverage intake. Other options do not directly confirm the tax's effectiveness in achieving the stated health outcomes.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: The city council claims that implementing a new bike-sharing program will reduce traffic congestion in the downtown area. The council points to a similar program in another city that reduced traffic by 15% as supporting evidence. Which of the following, if true, most weakens the argument?

options.A: The downtown area has fewer bike lanes compared to the other city.
options.B: The other city also implemented new public transportation routes at the same time as the bike-sharing program.
options.C: The population of the city is expected to grow significantly in the next year.
options.D: Residents of the downtown area have shown a strong preference for driving over cycling.
options.E: The bike-sharing program in the other city was subsidized by local businesses.

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) Conclusion: The new bike-sharing program will reduce traffic congestion. (2) Key assumption: The bike-sharing program alone caused the reduction in traffic. (3) Option B introduces an alternative explanation, showing that new public transport could be responsible for the traffic reduction, thus weakening the argument. (4) Other options do not directly address the causal link between the bike program and reduced traffic.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A recent study claims that students who study in short, regular intervals retain more information than those who study in longer, infrequent sessions. Which of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?

options.A: Students who study in longer sessions often report feeling more stressed and tired.
options.B: Regular breaks during study sessions are known to improve focus and concentration.
options.C: The study was conducted with students across multiple universities in diverse fields.
options.D: Some students prefer to study in longer sessions because they find it more comfortable.
options.E: Students who studied in short intervals reported higher test scores across various subjects.

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) Conclusion: Short, regular study intervals improve retention. (2) Key assumption: Such study patterns lead to better academic performance. (3) Option E directly supports the assumption by providing evidence of improved test scores, thus strengthening the argument. (4) Other options do not directly link study intervals to retention outcomes.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: Researchers have found that people who drink coffee regularly tend to live longer. They concluded that coffee consumption directly contributes to longevity. Which of the following, if true, most weakens the argument?

options.A: Regular coffee drinkers also tend to exercise more frequently than non-coffee drinkers.
options.B: Coffee contains antioxidants that are known to have health benefits.
options.C: The study included participants from a wide range of age groups and ethnic backgrounds.
options.D: People who avoid coffee often have different dietary preferences compared to coffee drinkers.
options.E: Coffee drinkers reported fewer visits to the doctor than non-coffee drinkers.

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) Conclusion: Coffee consumption leads to longer life. (2) Key assumption: Coffee directly causes longevity, not other factors. (3) Option A suggests that exercise, a known contributor to longevity, could explain the correlation, weakening the argument by introducing an alternative cause. (4) Other options do not sufficiently challenge the causal link between coffee and longevity.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A company claims that their newly developed app will significantly reduce water wastage by alerting users to leaks and excessive usage. Which of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?

options.A: The app includes a feature that automatically shuts off water supply when a leak is detected.
options.B: Similar apps have struggled to gain a significant user base in the past.
options.C: The app requires users to manually input their water usage data.
options.D: The app offers tips on how to reduce overall water consumption.
options.E: Users have reported difficulty in setting up the app on their devices.

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) Conclusion: The app will reduce water wastage. (2) Key assumption: The app effectively prevents water loss. (3) Option A strengthens the argument by showing that the app has a proactive feature that directly addresses leaks, thereby potentially reducing wastage significantly. (4) Other options do not demonstrate the app's effectiveness in reducing actual water wastage.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question: A report claims that implementing a new work-from-home policy will increase employee productivity. The report is based on a survey where 70% of employees reported feeling more productive while working from home. Which of the following, if true, casts the most doubt on the conclusion?

options.A: Employees who preferred working from the office were less likely to participate in the survey.
options.B: The survey was conducted during a period of unusual weather, which may have influenced responses.
options.C: Some employees reported issues with internet connectivity while working from home.
options.D: Employees working from home have fewer interactions with their colleagues.
options.E: A similar policy in another company showed mixed results in terms of productivity.

questions.explanation: Analysis: (1) Conclusion: Work-from-home policy will increase productivity. (2) Key assumption: Survey results accurately reflect general employee productivity. (3) Option A suggests a sample bias, where less productive employees (preferring the office) were underrepresented, thus weakening the argument. (4) Other options do not directly challenge the survey's representativeness.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Premises:
1. All cats are animals.
2. All animals are mammals.
Conclusion: All cats are mammals.
Which conclusion logically follows?

options.C: Both premises and conclusion are invalid
options.D: Conclusion follows only if some animals are not mammals

questions.explanation: Using Venn diagrams or direct distribution: Since all cats are animals and all animals are mammals, by transitive reasoning, all cats must be mammals. The conclusion directly follows as per the rule of universal affirmatives.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Premises:
1. No birds are mammals.
2. Some birds are penguins.
Conclusions:
I. Some penguins are not mammals.
II. Some penguins are birds.
Which conclusion(s) logically follow?

options.E: Only I follows but not II

questions.explanation: Conclusion I follows because if no birds are mammals and some birds are penguins, then some penguins cannot be mammals. Conclusion II is true because some birds are penguins. Thus, both conclusions follow.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Premises:
1. Some cars are not electric.
2. All electric vehicles are eco-friendly.
Conclusions:
I. Some cars are eco-friendly.
II. No car is electric.
Which conclusion(s) logically follow?
questions.explanation: Conclusion I does not follow because while some cars not being electric does not imply some are eco-friendly. Conclusion II does not follow because the premises do not imply that no car is electric. Thus, neither conclusion follows.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Premises:
1. All scientists are curious.
2. No curious person is uncreative.
3. Some uncreative people are lazy.
Conclusions:
I. Some lazy people are not scientists.
II. Some scientists are not lazy.
III. All scientists are uncreative.
Which conclusion(s) logically follow?

options.D: I and III follow but not II

questions.explanation: Conclusion I follows since some uncreative people are lazy, they cannot be scientists as no scientist is uncreative. Conclusion II follows as some scientists being non-lazy is possible given that not all scientists are mentioned as lazy. Conclusion III is incorrect as all scientists being uncreative contradicts the premises.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Premises:
1. All dancers are artists.
2. Some artists are not painters.
3. All painters are illustrators.
4. Some illustrators are not creative.
Conclusions:
I. Some dancers are not creative.
II. Some illustrators are not dancers.
III. No painter is a dancer.
IV. All dancers are illustrators.
Which conclusion(s) logically follow?
questions.explanation: Conclusion II follows, as some illustrators are not creative and no direct linkage exists between illustrators and all dancers. Conclusion I doesn't follow due to lack of direct link between dancers and creative. Conclusion III doesn't follow as no connection is established between painters and dancers directly. Conclusion IV doesn't follow as not all artists (dancers) are illustrators.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Premises:
1. All cats are mammals.
2. All mammals are animals.
Conclusion:
I. All cats are animals.
Which conclusion logically follows?
questions.explanation: Using the rule of syllogism, if all cats are mammals and all mammals are animals, then all cats must be animals. The premises follow the pattern: All A are B, All B are C, so All A are C.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Premises:
1. Some birds are sparrows.
2. All sparrows are animals.
Conclusions:
I. Some birds are animals.
II. All birds are animals.
Which conclusion(s) logically follow?
questions.explanation: From 'Some birds are sparrows' and 'All sparrows are animals', we can conclude 'Some birds are animals' as the sparrows that are birds are also animals. Conclusion II does not logically follow as not all birds are accounted for as sparrows.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Premises:
1. Some doctors are artists.
2. No artist is a businessman.
Conclusions:
I. Some doctors are not businessmen.
II. Some businessmen are doctors.
Which conclusion(s) logically follow?
questions.explanation: Conclusion I follows because, based on the premises, the doctors who are artists cannot be businessmen. Conclusion II does not follow because there is no evidence to suggest any businessmen are doctors.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Premises:
1. All lions are mammals.
2. Some mammals are carnivores.
3. All carnivores are predators.
Conclusions:
I. Some lions are predators.
II. All mammals are predators.
III. Some predators are mammals.
Which conclusion(s) logically follow?

options.C: Only conclusions I and III follow.

questions.explanation: Conclusion I does not follow because 'Some mammals are carnivores' does not specify whether the lions specifically are among them. Conclusion II does not follow because not all mammals are carnivores. Conclusion III follows because if some mammals are carnivores and all carnivores are predators, then some predators must indeed be mammals.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Premises:
1. All philosophers are thinkers.
2. Some thinkers are poets.
3. No poet is a painter.
Conclusions:
I. Some philosophers are poets.
II. Some thinkers are painters.
III. Some philosophers are not painters.
IV. No thinker is a painter.
Which conclusion(s) logically follow?

options.B: Only conclusions I and IV follow.
options.C: Only conclusions III and IV follow.

questions.explanation: Conclusion I does not follow as no connection between philosophers directly to poets is established. Conclusion II does not follow as there is no premise allowing a thinker to be a painter. Conclusion III follows because philosophers who are thinkers cannot be poets and thus not painters. Conclusion IV does not follow as some thinkers could be painters, there is no direct exclusion stated.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Premises:
1. All dogs are animals.
2. All animals are living beings.
Conclusions:
I. All dogs are living beings.
II. Some living beings are dogs.
Which conclusion(s) logically follow?
questions.explanation: All dogs are animals (A) and all animals are living beings (B), therefore all dogs are living beings (C). Since all dogs are living beings, it is true that some living beings are dogs. Therefore, both conclusions logically follow.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Premises:
1. Some cats are mammals.
2. All mammals are warm-blooded.
Conclusions:
I. Some cats are warm-blooded.
II. No cats are warm-blooded.
Which conclusion(s) logically follow?
questions.explanation: Since some cats are mammals and all mammals are warm-blooded, it logically follows that some cats are warm-blooded. Therefore, conclusion I follows. Conclusion II contradicts the premises.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Premises:
1. No birds are reptiles.
2. All reptiles lay eggs.
Conclusions:
I. No birds lay eggs.
II. Some egg-laying creatures are not birds.
Which conclusion(s) logically follow?
questions.explanation: From the premises, no birds are reptiles and all reptiles lay eggs. However, this does not mean no birds lay eggs, so conclusion I does not follow. Conclusion II follows as all reptiles (egg-laying creatures) are not birds.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Premises:
1. Some students are athletes.
2. No athletes are lazy.
3. All lazy people are gamers.
Conclusions:
I. Some students are not lazy.
II. Some athletes are gamers.
III. No students are gamers.
Which conclusion(s) logically follow?

options.B: Only conclusions I and III follow.

questions.explanation: Some students are athletes, and no athletes are lazy. Therefore, some students are not lazy (Conclusion I). Since no athletes are lazy and lazy people are gamers, no athletes can be gamers, thus II is incorrect. III does not necessarily follow.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Premises:
1. All managers are employees.
2. Some employees are not happy.
3. Some happy people are not managers.
Conclusions:
I. Some managers are not happy.
II. Some managers are happy.
III. All happy people are employees.
IV. Some non-managers are happy.
Which conclusion(s) logically follow?
questions.explanation: Since all managers are employees and some employees are not happy, it follows that some managers may not be happy (I). From premise 3, some happy people are not managers (IV). The premises do not support conclusions II or III.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Premises:
1. All cats are mammals.
2. All mammals are animals.
Conclusion:
I. All cats are animals.
Which conclusion logically follows?
questions.explanation: Using the transitive property of logic in syllogisms, since all cats are mammals and all mammals are animals, it follows that all cats are animals. The conclusion is valid according to the Barbara syllogism form (AAA-1).
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Premises:
1. Some birds are pigeons.
2. No pigeons are mammals.
Conclusions:
I. Some birds are not mammals.
II. All birds are mammals.
Which conclusion(s) logically follow?
questions.explanation: From the premises, it is clear that some birds are pigeons, and since no pigeons are mammals, some birds that are pigeons cannot be mammals. Therefore, some birds are not mammals follows logically.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Premises:
1. All fruits are food.
2. Some foods are not healthy.
Conclusions:
I. Some fruits are not healthy.
II. All foods are healthy.
Which conclusion(s) logically follow?
questions.explanation: The premises do not provide enough information to conclude that some fruits are not healthy, as we do not know if those foods that are not healthy are indeed fruits. Also, the statement "All foods are healthy" directly contradicts the premise that some foods are not healthy. Thus, neither conclusion follows.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Premises:
1. No dogs are cats.
2. Some cats are tigers.
3. All tigers are wild animals.
Conclusions:
I. Some wild animals are not dogs.
II. No cats are dogs.
III. Some tigers are dogs.
Which conclusion(s) logically follow?
questions.explanation: Conclusion I follows because, since some cats are tigers and all tigers are wild animals, and no dogs are cats, it is certain that some wild animals (those being tigers) are not dogs. Conclusion II follows directly from the premise that no dogs are cats. Conclusion III does not follow as it contradicts the first premise. Thus, conclusions I and II follow.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Premises:
1. All roses are flowers.
2. Some flowers are white.
3. No white things are books.
Conclusions:
I. Some roses are not books.
II. All flowers are books.
III. Some white things are not roses.
IV. No roses are books.
Which conclusion(s) logically follow?
questions.explanation: Conclusion I follows because, as some flowers are white and no white things are books, those flowers that are both roses and white cannot be books. Conclusion III follows directly from the fact that some flowers are white and no white things are books, thus some white things (those that are flowers but not roses) are not roses. Conclusion II is false as it contradicts the third premise. Conclusion IV cannot be concluded as it overextends the logical deduction.
questions.subject: Reasoning

questions.question:
Premises:
1. All dogs are animals.
2. All animals are living beings.
Conclusions:
